loans.name: Mansueta

texts.en:
Mansueta B. manages a general store. She is 51 years old and already a widow. She is blessed with three children – two of them are college graduates and have their own jobs. Mansueta works hard to provide her children access to higher education. She is thankful because, through the business she manages, she is able to support her children during their school days.

Mansueta would like to continue improving her store for financial security as she grows older. In this regard, she would like to ask for additional capital from Kiva lenders of 5,000 Philippine pesos for expansion and to buy additional groceries for her store. She will be glad if this amount is approved.

loans.use: Additional capital for her vending business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rosie

texts.en: Rosie is a 33-year-old farmer from Surallah, South Cotabato. She enjoys working in her rice field to earn a living. She started farming in 2008. She has five children; the eldest is 14 years old. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to be able to obtain a loan. She requested 15,000 Philippine pesos to buy fertilizers and farm inputs. She is thankful that CEVI is offering a loan that has a low interest rate. This loan will be very helpful to sustain her business and family.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and farm inputs

loans.name: Wilfreda

texts.en: With her rice farming business, Wilfreda is able to provide the needs of her family. She is 52 years old and lives in Surallah, South Cotabato. She has four children; the eldest is 19 years old. She wants to continue sending her children to school by providing them with their tuition fees and school supplies. She heard about Community Economic Ventures, Inc. offering loans to entrepreneurs like her. On June 2008, she joined and is thankful for the low interest charged. Now she is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP to purchase farm supplies.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Chera Mae

texts.en: Chera Mae, at the age of 19, has a business raising hogs. She started her business in 2007. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. because of its good program in micro financing. She is now requesting a loan of 12,000 PHP to buy more pigs and feed. This loan will enable her to raise more pigs and earn more for a living. As of now, she has eight pigs, but she is looking forward to raising more by having additional capital for her business.

loans.use: To buy pigs and feed

loans.name: Sveta's Group

texts.en:
Sveta is the leader of this group. She could regard herself as the happiest person just because of where she lives. She lives in a beauty spot – Bokonbaevo village. Especially at this time of the year, the trees and fields turn gold, yellow and red. In contrast to this, you can see a multitude of carefree cattle, easily visible against this marvelous background, munching the appetizing weed.
Sveta has had a big ordeal – the death of her husband. Having reached the age of 49, she has been left with their only child, a daughter. Back when her spouse was alive, they used to raise livestock and had a pretty decent life. At that time, her husband took care of everything. After the misfortune, she had to take the initiative into her own hands and, with the help of her friends, she started to raise livestock, feed it, and sell it at the cattle market. Trading in cattle used to be her husband’s occupation; now it has also become Sveta’s way of life.
Five years ago, Sveta invested $230 USD in purchasing cattle, and she has achieved considerable success in this business. On average, she makes $140 USD a month – a stable income, which is 60 per cent of her initial investment. Sveta is eager to expand her trade. She has applied for this loan to enable her to purchase more cattle for subsequent resale. One of her plans for the near future is to buy a two-chamber fridge.

Sveta’s group partners:
Tilek, 58, is a widow. She has four grandchildren. She raises livestock, and needs a loan to purchase cattle.
Erkimbek, 43, has three children. To provide for his family, Erkimbek raises cattle and works as a taxi driver. He needs a loan to purchase hay.
Salyi, 57, is divorced. She trades in cattle, and her only son, 33, helps her in this business. She hopes to obtain this loan to buy cattle.
Nurlan, 46, is a father of three children. He works for the government and combines this work with animal husbandry. He needs a loan to buy cattle.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young, ambitious and socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year.
To learn more about Mol Bulak and to view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Despite the hardships and difficulties of life, Alma B. and her husband want to send their three children to school so that they will find good jobs someday. They sacrifice their time and endure hardships for the sake of their children. The family lives in the village of Barangay Capatan, Tuguegarao City.

As a way of making a living, Alma's husband cultivates a farm lot, planting rice and vegetables, and sometimes he manages a blacksmith business. Alma sells snacks and vegetables in their village to help her husband make income. She wants to sell more snacks and vegetables but she doesn't have enough capital. Therefore, she wants to borrow 5,000 Philippine pesos from Kiva lenders to be used to improve her small business. She hopes that with patience and sacrifice, and with this financial assistance, she can make her business grow.

loans.use: Additional capital for her vending business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en: Erlinda, 58, manages a piggery business in Surallah, South Cotabato. She supports nine children – that's why she works hard to earn more income. Aside from the piggery, she also has a business in rice farming and poultry. She would like to expand her businesses but has limited capital. She sought financial help from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to fill the needs of her business. She requested 15,000 Philippine pesos to buy more pigs and farm and poultry supplies. This loan will let her continue expanding her businesses.

loans.use: To buy pigs and farm supplies

loans.name: Nazgul's Group

texts.en:
The lives of people are filled with useful experiences. They are diverse like people themselves. Different people have different ordeals. It is believed that strong people have more difficult ordeals. However, steadfastness and hope for better always help people to live through them. Besides, there are always people around us who are there to support us in difficult moments. Those are our parents, closest relatives and friends. The leader of this group, Nazgul, a 28-year-old young woman, deserves to be called a strong woman. The ordeal that awaited her was divorce after a few years of happy marriage. The expectations of cozy and agreeable married life did not come true. Instead, after divorce actually took place, she was left with two children to raise and uncertainty about life in the future. Nazgul wisely viewed things in a sensible light. She talked to her parents and they agreed to help her look after her five–year-old son and three–year-old daughter while Nazgul is at work as a hospital nurse. Her parents have also given her some sheep for breeding and so animal husbandry became Nazgul’s second occupation. Although she only earns about $95 per month, she can always sell some of her cattle to satisfy her family's needs. Nazgul wants to increase the total population of her cattle and is therefore requesting a loan to buy a calf.

There are three partners in Nazgul’s group:

Asigul, 60, has raised four children and is married to a vice principal of music college. Asigul is a housewife who keeps some cattle and needs a loan to buy a cow.

Burulbu, 59, has one son, a boxing trainer. and a retired husband. For a living, Burulbu raises livestock and sells milk. She hopes to obtain a loan to buy a cow.

Kuljamal, 56, a mother of five children, is married to a shepherd. Kuljamal stays at home and looks after cattle and sells milk. She has applied for this loan to buy a milk cow.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy a calf for resale

loans.name: Samkoarl

texts.en: Mr. Samkoarl P. is 30 years old.  He lives in Ank village in Kandal province. He is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare field of land where he cultivates rice. He needs some money to buy rice seed, fertilizers, and gasoline, and to pay the laborers who work on the rice field. His wife, Mrs. Kim Touch, is employed in a garment factory. Mr. Samkoarl P. is the father of a child who is just 4 years old. His wife is shown in the picture with him.

loans.use: to buy rice seed, fertilizers, and gasoline, and to pay the laborers who work on the rice field

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ly

texts.en:
Ly S. A., 46 years old, lives with her own small family in Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. Ly S. A. is a good homemaker who stays A. home to either care for the children or do housework. She also cultivates a rice crop during the approaching farming season. Ly S. A. is married and blessed with eight children, one of whom works in construction.

Her husband is a local construction foreman who has many employees who help provide his service. Ly S. A. requests a loan for her husband to use as capital to purchase more building equipment in order to better provide for the needs of his customers.

loans.use: Purchase more building equipment to better provide for the needs of customers

loans.name: Khon

texts.en: Mrs. Khon P. lives in Cheak village in Kandal province. She is a fruit seller in the local market. Her husband, Mr. Sok Eav, is a farmer who hires a piece of land to cultivate rice on. In this plantation, he faces an obstacle because he does not have money to expend for his growing. In order to deal with this problem, Mrs. Khon P. decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer, and gasoline to pump water to support the rice field. This couple has two children, one of whom is a laborer while the other stays at home to do housework. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: to buy rice seed, fertilizer, and gasoline to pump water to support the rice field

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn R.'s main source of income comes from raising pigs for sale. She is 28 years old, single and has two school-age children. They are from the village of Quezon. Evelyn earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) when she sells her pigs.

In 2009, Evelyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Evelyn is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be her first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Roselyn

texts.en:
Roselyn L. is a 41-year-old married woman who lives in a town in Agusan del Sur. She has seven children. Her oldest is now 21 years old. She has to work hard to provide for her family. She dreams that someday her family’s living conditions will be better.

Roselyn is involved in rice farming. She also has a stall at the public market where she sells her rice. She is now preparing her land for the next planting. She will need seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She requested a loan of 9,000 Philippine pesos from CEVI, which she will use to purchase the farm inputs she needs.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Mary Jean

texts.en: Mary Jean farms for a living. She is 36 years old, married and has two children. Her oldest child is only 11 years old, going to school. She cultivates her farm for rice crops. She works hard to cover her family’s needs and her kids’ education. She is now preparing her farm for planting. She applied for a loan of 9,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use this loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs to be used on her farm. This loan will help Mary Jean sustain her farm and her family.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Phath

texts.en: Mrs. Phath P. is a villager in Ank village in Kandal province. She is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare field to cultivate rice on. In her plantation, she faces some problems because her field is far from the irrigation system and it has infertile soil which has a bad effect on her crops. Thus, she decided to request a loan to buy a water pump, rice seed, fertilizer, and gasoline. She is 43 years old and a widow with a child who is a farmer who helps with the mother’s work.

loans.use: to buy a water pump, rice seed, fertilizer, and gasoline

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Liza

texts.en: Liza is 47 years old and has a hog raising business. She is married to Sonny and has six children to support. Her additional sources of income are rice farming and a duckery. Liza has limited capital to do business – that's why she sought help from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to obtain a loan. Now she would like to request 15,000 Philippine pesos to buy more pigs. This loan will help her continue her business with a low interest charge.

loans.use: To buy pigs and feed

loans.name: Riobelyn

texts.en:
Riobelyn is a 25-year-old married woman with two children. Her oldest child is only five years old. She works hard to provide for the family and save for her children’s future. She started her farming business when she got married. She plants rice crops in her field. Currently, she has a 1.3-hectare rice field, which according to her, produces at least 60 sacks of rice. 

Riobelyn joined CEVI in February of this year. She said that even though she is a new member, she can already say that its program is very helpful to farmers like her, especially its low interest rate of 2% per month. She is now requesting a loan of PHP9,000. She will use this loan to buy seeds, fertilizer and other farm inputs needed at her farm. She will also be able to pay the laborers she hired to work on her farm.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizer and other farm supplies

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina, 43 years old, is involved in rice farming. She is married and has two children. Her oldest child is now 21. She tills her rice field with patience. She makes sure to be strong and healthy to do the work required on her farm. She wants to earn more to improve her family’s living condition.

Regina used to borrow money from individuals who charge high interest. This brought difficulty in maintaining her farm and providing for the family. When she heard of CEVI, she immediately joined and was fortunate to qualify as a member. She used her previous loan to finance her farm. Out of her income from the farm, she was able to pay her obligations and provide for her family’s growing needs. She is now requesting a loan of PHP9,000. She will use this loan to purchase farm inputs needed at her farm. This loan will help Regina maintain her farm’s good condition.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Indera's Group

texts.ru:
Калчаева Индера – лидер данной группы. Индера и её семья живут в г. Кант, всего в двадцати километрах от столицы. Это обычная семья, которая, как и многие другие семьи, трудится изо дня в день, чтобы прокормить себя и находит удовольствие в самом труде. Повседневный труд простых людей со средним достатком действительно прививает чувство довольства. Человек находит наслаждение и счастье в повседневных заботах и ещё больше прилагает стараний и усилий, чтобы продлить удовольствие. Муж Индеры работает на предприятии «Кант строй» простым рабочим. Индера – домохозяйка и мать троих детей. Старшей дочери семнадцать лет. Недавно её выдали замуж. Затем её сын. Ему шестнадцать лет. Он учится в восьмом классе. Самой младшей дочери всего пять лет. Она ходит в детский сад. Индера помимо повседневных хлопот по дому, также держит скот и занимается домашним хозяйством. Она занимается животноводством с тех пор, как свёкор подарил ей три барана, чтобы Индера и её муж могли потихоньку разводить овец и увеличивать поголовье. Что и сделала Индера. Она умело распорядилась щедрым подарком свёкра и впоследствии благодаря общим усилиям Индеры, её мужа и детей, они размножили овец. И когда Индера выдавала старшую дочь замуж, она с лёгкостью встретила сватов, так как уже имела овец, т.е. запас мяса. Теперь Индера обратилась за кредитом, чтобы купить тёлку. У Индеры есть мечта построить большой дом. 

В группе Индеры три партнёра:

Куанишиной Анжелике тридцать черыре года. У Анжелики трое детей. Муж Анжелики работает разнорабочим на «Сахзаводе». Сама Анжелика работает оператором розлива на «Сахзаводе». Вместе с этим у неё имеется скот, за которым ухаживают её родители. Анжелика нуждается в кредите, чтобы купить несколько овец для разведения и продажи приплода. 

Калчаеву Асанбеку шестьдесят три года. Асанбек – пенсионер. Жена – домохозяйка. У них четверо дочерей. Все замужем и живут отдельно. Асанбек держит скот и сдаёт молоко по пятнадцать литров в день. Продажа молока и пенсия позволяют Асанбеку жить, не завися ни от кого. Асанбеку нужен кредит, чтобы купить несколько овец. 

Сейдохматовой Гулжан тридцать пять лет. У Гульжан две дочери. Муж Гулжан работает мастером в «Кант строй». Гулжан дома с младшей дочкой. Она ухаживает за скотом и продаёт молоко. Гулжан надеется получить кредит, который позволит ей купить две овцы. 


--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Indera K. is the leader of this group. Indera and her family live in the city of Kant, only twenty minutes from the capital. Kalchaevs are an average family, and like so many others, they work day after day to feed themselves and find enjoyment in the work itself. Everyday work of simple people with an average income can often bring a feeling of contentment. A person can find joy and happiness in taking care of everyday concerns and with each day tries to apply even more effort and dedication. Indera's husband is a worker at the "Kant stroi" construction company. Indera takes care of the household and is a mother of three children. The eldest daughter is seventeen. She recently got married. Indera's son is sixteen. He is an eighth-grade student. The youngest daughter is only five, and she attends kindergarden. In addition to doing everyday work around the house, Indera raises farm animals. She has been in the livestock breeding business ever since her father-in-law gave her three rams, so that she and her husband could breed sheep and little-by-little increase the headcount. That's exactly what Indera proceeded to do. She skilfully used the generous gift of her father-in-law, and thanks to the joint efforts of Indera, her husband, and her children, they were able to create their own flock. When the time came for her eldest daugher to get married Indera was prepared, since she already enough meat. Now Indera is seeking a loan in order to purchase a cow calf. Indera's dream is to build a big house.

Indera has three partners in her group: Anzhelika K. is thirty-four. She has three children. Anzhelika's husband is a worker at the "Sahzavod" company. Anzhelika herself works as a distribution operator at "Sahzavod". She also has livestock that is tended by her parents. Anzhelika needs a loan in order to purchase several sheep for livestock breeding and sales. Asanbek K. is sixty-three. Asanbek is a pensionier. His wife works at home. They have four daughters who are married and live separately. Asanbek tends his livestock and sells fifteen litres of milk per day. The sale of milk and his pension allow Asanbek to live independently. Asanbek needs a load to purchase several sheep. Gulzhan S. is thirty-five. She has two daughters. Gulzhan's husband works as a supervisor at "Kant stroi".Gulzhan stays at home with her youngest daughter. She tends the livestock and sells milk. Gulzhan hopes to obtain a loan that would allow her to purchase two additional sheep.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

Translated from Russian by Andrei Vazhnov, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Ban

texts.en: Ban S. is a 32-year-old woman and lives with her own family in Phnom Penh city. Ban S. is a good housewife who cooks delicious meals for her family. She now takes care of four school-aged children, while her husband named Seang Sothea, age 34, works in a military department. Since the mature rice season is coming, Ban S. is looking for a US$ 1200 loan to use as capital to order mature rice in bulk from farmers during the time when rice commands the cheapest price. She will sell it for a profit when the rice is at its highest cost.

loans.use: To order mature rice in bulk from farmers when rice commands the cheapest price

loans.name: Alejandra

texts.en:
46-year-old Alejandra does farming for a living. She lives with her husband and their six children. Her oldest is 17 years old and one of her goals is to give her children a proper education. She stays strong despite the hard work required on her farm. Her farm needs additional capital.

Alejandra joined CEVI to gain access to loan opportunities. She is now requesting PHP9,000. She will use this loan to finance her farm. This loan will help Alejandra save for her children’s education.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Esterlita

texts.en:
Esterlita is a 45-year-old entrepreneur from Trinidad, Bohol. She is married and has four children. Her oldest child is now 24 years old. She is involved in fishing and still wants to pursue other types of business. She wants to buy pigs that will serve as another source of income. She said that she has to earn more to meet the growing needs of her family, especially her children’s education.

Esterlita is a member of CEVI. She likes its program and sees it as God’s way of helping her family. She requested a loan of PHP13,000. She will use this loan to buy nets and other fishing equipment, and to acquire pigs that she will raise.

loans.use: To buy fishing equipment and pigs

loans.name: Yoeun

texts.en: Mr. Yoeun N. is a villager in Chi Chrab village in Takeo province. He is a construction worker. Since his work place is far from the house, he faces an obstacle because he usually pays a lot of money for motorbike taxis. Thus, he decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike to drive to work and reduce his expenditure.  His wife, Mrs. Sorn Sarun, is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice on. This couple has a child who is too young to work or study. His wife is also in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike to drive to work

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en: Marilyn is a rice farmer. She is 41 years old and has been married to her husband Ricardo for 29 years now. They have a seven-year-old child. Work at the farm is tedious, but Marilyn stays strong helping her husband tend their farm. She shared that her farm currently needs inputs. She applied for a loan from CEVI of PHP4,000. This loan will be used for farm inputs like fertilizer and others. This loan will also help Marilyn be active in their business life.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Rosa's Group

texts.en:
Rosa, the leader of this group, has four children. Rosa, 44, has been divorced for some years. She had to raise her children without anybody’s help. However she has been fortunate to have sensible and clever children, who always strive to help and ease Rosa’s burden. Her eldest daughter is twenty-five. She is working in Alma-Ata city. Among Rosa’s children for right now, she is the only one who is able to help Rosa to support the family and pay for the other children’s education.

Rosa's son is twenty. He wants to be a lawyer and studies at a law college. Another daughter is obtaining tuition by correspondence. To meet the family's needs, Rosa has to combine two jobs. She runs a shop near her house and as well, raises livestock. She started raising livestock fifteen years ago, when she and her husband bought two cows. Back then, they invested around 185 US$ in purchasing those two cows. Having bred cattle for all these years, she has been able to increase the total population. Now she sells thirty liters of milk a day and thus earns 210 US$.

Rosa wants to sell more milk. She has applied for this loan and hopes to buy one more cow.

Rosa has three partners:

Oksana, 24, is divorced. She has two children. Oksana works as an operator at “Abdysh – Ata” brewery. Besides, she has a cow and makes additional money by selling milk. Oksana needs a loan to buy a sheep and a cow.

Kulbaira, 43, is divorced. She has a son, 25, and a daughter, 23. Her children work and help their mother. As for Kulbaira, she earns her living by working as a baker. She also keeps a cow and sells milk. Kulbaira needs a loan to buy a calf.

Shirin, 47, is divorced. She has two daughters. One of her daughters is a housewife. Another works as an accountant. Shirin owns a shop in a village and has a cow. She hopes to obtain a loan and buy another cow. She is going to pay two-thirds of the price from her own savings.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable, to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan which delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To buy a cow to sell more milk

loans.name: Ines

texts.en: Ines is involved in a buy & sell kind of business. She is 38 years old, married and has four kids. Her oldest is only 18. A majority of what she sells is dried fish. She also acquires bananas and other vegetables and sells them in their community. Ines shares that she needs additional capital for her business. She joined CEVI to gain access to its financial program. She requested a loan of PHP10,000. With this loan, Ines will be able to buy fish and other vegetables. Ines is hopeful that this loan will help her achieve her dream to grow her business.

loans.use: To buy dried fish and vegetables

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en: 32-year-old Analiza sells agricultural products for a living. She has been married to her husband Cesar for 11 years. She prays for her business to grow so that her family’s living conditions will improve. She currently needs additional capital. She turned to an MFI, Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She applied for a loan of PHP8,000. She will use this loan to buy products like bananas and other crops. This loan will help grow Analiza’s business.

loans.use: To purchase bananas and other crops

loans.name: Krin

texts.en: Mrs. Krin N. is 40 years old and she lives in Chuos village in Takeo province. She breeds ducks and chickens. Since her duck breeding business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more ducklings and duck food for breeding. Her husband, Mr. Hun Nhor, is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. This couple has five children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while another is a security guard; two are attending the local school and the remaining stays at home. Her husband is presented on the left of photo.

loans.use: By purchasing more ducklings and duck food for breeding.

loans.name: Heang

texts.en:
Mr. Heang P. is a villager in Srae Ampil village in Kandal province. He is a motorbike taxi driver.

Mr. Heang P.’s wife, Mrs. Thy Mary, is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice to earn a living. In this plantation, she faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money for her cultivating. Thus, Mr. Heang P. decided to ask for a loan to buy farming supplies for her rice paddy.

Mr. Heang P. is 55 years old and the father of three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the other stays at home to do housework. His wife is shown on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies for his wife's rice paddy

loans.name: Ainake's Group

texts.ru:
Токтошбаева Айнаке – лидер данной группы. Айнаке живёт в г. Карабалта. Это в шестидесяти километрах от столицы. Пятидесяти восьми летняя Айнаке по праву может считать себя сильной и мужественной женщиной. Ведь Айнаке вырастила ни многим, ни малым аж семерых детей. У Айнаке шесть дочерей и один сын. Старшей дочери сорок восемь лет, а младшей – двадцать два года. Даже после того, как умер муж, Айнаке мужественно продолжила в одиночку воспитание детей. Сейчас, к счастью всего дочери замужем, и единственный сын женат. Сын после смерти отца, женившись, решил жить с матерью и помогать ей. От мужа Айнаке по наследству досталась кое – какая живность. Посоветовавшись с родственниками и детьми, Айнаке решила оставить скот и не продавать его. Айнаке пришлось учиться ухаживанию за скотом. Благо, что сын был рядом и помогал. Время само показало, насколько мудрым оказалось её решение. Айнаке увеличила поголовье и при выдаче замуж дочерей, и при женитьбе сына, этот же самый скот очень пригодился. Айнаке сэкономила значительные средства, так как ей не пришлось покупать мяса. Сейчас, Айнаке продаёт молоко и этим самым покрывает свои повседневные расходы. Когда ей нужна большая сумма, сын может отвести живность на базар и продать. Айнаке надеется приобрести ещё одну корову, чтобы увеличить прибыль от молока. В её планы также входит сделать капитальный ремонт дома и поставить новые ворота. 

У Айнаке три партнёра по группе:

Тукуеву Элдияру тридцать семь лет. У Элдияра двое детей. Жена – домохозяйка. Чтобы прокормить семью Элдияр занимается разведением овец и продажей молока. Эльдияр нуждается в кредите. Он хочет купить ещё одну корову. У Эльдияра есть заветная мечта – построить дом на фазенде. 

Дуйшенкуловой Гульзат тридцать четыре года. Муж Гульзат работает контролёром – электриком. У них трое детей. Младшей дочери всего четыре годика. Все дети ходят в младшую школу. Гульзат дома ухаживает за скотом. Она обратилась за кредитом, чтобы купить корову. 

Орозалиевой Айнуре сорок девять лет. Айнура, вместе с мужем вырастили четверых детей: три дочери и одного сына. Все дочери замужем. Сыну всего одиннадцать. Он ходит в школу. Муж Айнуры работает управляющим частной фермы. Сама Айнура держит скот, а также дома занимается вышиванием и продажей национальных изделий. Айнура надеется получить кредит и приобрести корову.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Ainake T. is the leader of this group. Ainake lives in the city of Karbalta, sixty kilometers from the capital. A fifty-eight-year-old widow Ainake has earned the right to consider herself a strong and courageous woman, because she has raised seven children: six daughters and one son. The eldest daughter is now thirty-eight, the youngest is twenty-two. After her husband passed away Ainake courageously continued raising her children by herself. Fortunately today all the daughters and the only son are married. After the death of his father Ainake's son decided to stay and help her run the household. From her husband Ainake inherited a few animals. After discussing it with her children and relatives Ainake decided to keep the livestock rather than sell it. She had to learn how to tend for the animals. She was very fortunate that her son was right there, helping her along the way. Time itself has shown just how wise her decision was. She was able to increase the headcount of her livestock and when the time came for her children to be married this livestock came very handy. Ainake saved a lot of money since she didn't have to purchase meat. Currently Ainake sells milk and that's how she earns income for her living expenses. Whenever she needs a larger amount her son sells some of the livestock on the local market. Ainake is hoping to purchase an additional cow to increase the profits from the sale of milk. She is planning to do renovations in her house and also replace the gates.

Ainake has three partners in her group: Eldiar T. is thirty-seven. He has two children. His wife stays at home with the children. To feed his family Eldiar raises sheep and sells milk. He needs the loan in order to buy one more cow. He has a dream to build a house on his farm. Gulzat D. is thirty-four. Her husband is an electrician. They have three children. The youngest daughter is only four. All children go to primary school. Gulzat stays at home tending the livestock. She is asking for a loan in order to purchase a cow. Ainura O. is forty-nine. With her husband Ainura raised four children: three daughters and one son. All the daughters are married. The son attends school, he is only eleven. Ainura's husband works as a manager of a farm. At home Ainura tends her livestock as well as knits and sells local souvenirs. Ainura is hoping to get a loan in order to buy a cow.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

Translated from Russian by Andrei Vazhnov, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a cow to sell more milk

loans.name: Long

texts.en:
Long N., 44, has established a small family home in the best territory of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. Long N. is a homemaker who cooks tasty foods for her family and cares for children. She was married years ago and is blessed with six children. Two of them are married and live independently, while the other four are students. This family is supported by Long N.’s husband, who works as a civil service officer for a committee consultant department.

Long N. will be using her first loan to buy a used motorbike for her school-aged children to use to ride to their place of study.

loans.use: To buy a used motorbike for her school-aged children to ride to their study place

loans.name: Sarin

texts.en:
Mr. Sarin S. lives in Neal village in Takeo province. He owns more speakers which have been hired by the villagers to play during wedding, ceremonies, party, and so on.

Mr. Sarin S.’s wife, Mrs. Khat Nam, is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice. In this plantation, she faces a problem because her field is far from the irrigation system. In order to deal with this problem, Mr. Sarin S. decided to ask for a loan to buy a water pump to irrigate the rice field.

Mr. Sarin S. is 48 years old and the father of three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while another is attending the local school and the remaining one stays at home to do housework. His wife is shown in the photo with him.

loans.use: To buy a water pump to irrigate his wife's rice field

loans.name: Hoeurn

texts.en:
Mrs. Hoeurn K. is a villager in Neal village in TaK. province. She is a duck breeder. She sells duck eggs in the local market. Her poultry business is going well, so she wants to expand it by purchasing more ducks for breeding. She hopes to increase her income and improve the family living.

Her husband, Mr. Meas Soeun (pictured here), is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare field of land to cultivate rice. Mrs. Hoeurn K. is 52 years old and the mother of four children; one is employed in a garment factory, two are enrolled in the local school, and the other child stays at home to do housework.

loans.use: Purchase more ducks for breeding

loans.name: Nhem

texts.en:
Mr. Nhem B., 52, is a teacher of English. He teaches at a local public school. He earns a salary of $80 each month, which helps contribute to providing for his family’s daily food. Nhem B. is married to Choup Reum, age 53, who sells a few vegetables to earn some money.

This couple has been married for years and is blessed to have eight children; one is married, and the other seven attend school. Nhem B. is asking for a Kiva loan to add to his small amount of savings in order to buy a new motorbike for his children to ride to school.

loans.use: Buy a new motorbike for his children to ride to school

loans.name: Mrs. Neang Chhom Village Bank Group

texts.en:
A group village bank loan consists of eleven people, who live in New Chrouy Ampil village in Kandal province. All the members will use the loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Neang C. is the village bank president. She is a grocer and now she wants to expand her business by purchasing more grocery products to resell to earn more income. Her husband, Mr. Preab Saroin, is a soldier. Mrs. Neang C. is 39 years old and the mother of four children; three are enrolled in the local school, and the youngest one is just 4 years old.

loans.use: Purchase more grocery products to resell to earn more income

loans.name: Cristy

texts.en:
Cristy and her husband Baltazar reside in the village of Barangay Capatan Tuguegarao, City. Their main source of income is a motorcycle transport business. Additionally, Cristy is also engaged in farming, while her husband Baltazar is a tricycle operator in their village to earn extra income. 

In order to further develop his transportation business, Cristy is requesting a loan amounting to PHP 5,000 from the KIVA lenders. He hopes that this loan request will be approved so that he can maintain his motorcycle transport and have his business grow and earn more of a profit.

Cristy and Baltazar are blessed with only one child namedLucky 24 years old, college graduate. He is now working as a Traffic Enforcer in Tuguegarao, City.

loans.use: Additional capital for the maintenance of her husband's vehicle

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en: Elvira S. is 53 years old. She is married to Jose S. who is a local farmer. They are living in the peaceful Barangay (village) of Capatan Tuguegarao, City. Elvira is well known in the village as a good and friendly neighbor. Elvira is engaged in beauty services. She offers manicures, pedicures, and hair cutting and she earns a daily income of PHP250.00. Elvira wants to obtain a loan from KIVA lenders amounting to PHP5,000 to invest in her business and for the education of her only child. She hopes and prays that KIVA lenders will grant her loan in order for her to have a productive business.

loans.use: To buy materials for her beauty service

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida Z. is from the city of Capatan Tuguegarao, City. She is 42 years old. Nida is married and has seven adult children. To make a living, Nida pantins & harvests fruits & vegetables for sale. Nida is just starting this business.

In 2007, Nida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Nida is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Nida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more items to sell

loans.name: Lilieth

texts.en: Lilieth T. is from the village of Bungad San Pablo, Isabela. She is 35 years old. Lilieth is married and has 6 school-aged children. Lilieth owns & operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Lilieth has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP whenever she sells her raised pigs. In 2008, Lilieth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lilieth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. Lilieth is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Lilieth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 21 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth B. is from the village of Bungad San Pablo, Isabela. She is 45 years old. Elizabeth is married and has 5 school-aged children. Elizabeth owns & operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing repair services to local community members. Elizabeth has been engaged in her business for over 19 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2007, Elizabeth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elizabeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase materials needed to expand the services provided. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase equipment to improve the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Elizabeth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase equipment to improve the business

loans.name: Yem

texts.en:
Yem V. is 35 years old and is a resident of the rural area of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. She is a divorced woman who currently works as a garment worker. She lives with 5 children; two are employed, and the others are going to school.

Beside her current work, Yem V. plants a rice crop for extra income when the rice season arrives. Yem V. is requesting a loan to buy a cow, which will alleviate her hard labor on the farm.

loans.use: To buy a cow for farmwork

loans.name: Ushirika Mazizini Group

texts.en:
Pamela Cheseo, age 25, is married, with one 4-year-old son. She has a clothes, bag, and cosmetics business since 2005. She works daily from 7 am until 4 pm. She is able to make a monthly profit of around $121.

This will be Pamela’s fifth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to increase the stock for her business, and she successfully paid back her loans. She is requesting this loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to further increase her inventory.

Pamela will share this loan with her loan group, Ushirika Mazizini, which has 16 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable to pay back their loans. In the picture, Pamela is the first person on the left in the front row.

loans.use: Increase inventory for clothes, bag, and cosmetics business

loans.name: Teresita  C. Pascual Group

texts.en: Teresita C. P. is from the village of Mocag Baggao, Cagayan. She is 55 years old. Teresita is the group leader of an 11 member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Teresita is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Teresita owns & operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month from these activities. In 2009, Teresita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Teresita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Soeurn

texts.en:
Mrs. Soeurn M. lives in Tuol Svay village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she cultivates rice. On this plantation, she faces an obstacle because her field has infertile soil and she does not have enough money to pay for plowing. Thus, she is requesting a loan to buy fertilizers and to pay for plowing.

Her husband, Mr. Nhang Nhorn (pictured on the right), is a teacher in the local school. Mrs. Soeurn M. is 55 years old and the mother of six children; two are employed in a garment factory, two are enrolled in the local school, and the remaining child stays at home to do housework.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer and pay for plowing

loans.name: Khasiya

texts.en:
Khasiya Q. is a very hard-working woman and knows that each day she has to give her best effort and all her courage. She is married and has ten children.

Khasiya works raising cattle and feeding them, with the goal of later selling them. This activity gives her feelings of satisfaction, because it allows her to provide a considerable amount of the household income. She makes sure not to neglect her role as a mother, because she’s also very dedicated to lovingly raising her adorable children.

Khasiya wants to improve her stable stalls and produce milk in a quantity sufficient for selling it commercially. This is the reason that she is requesting a loan of 1606 AZN to buy small cattle and fodder for her animals. Please support this woman who is determined to change the course of her life with dedication and hard work.

loans.use: Purchase three cattle and fodder

loans.name: Lala

texts.en:
Lala H. is a 55-year-old married woman who lives with her four children and owns a small farm. She lives and works in a small village in the Southern part of Azerbaijan. Lala, together with her husband, have been running a business raising and selling sheep. She has 14 years of experience in this field.

Sheep raising and selling is a profitable business, and Lala has become a very successful businesswoman in a very short period. The income is enough to cover her family's needs, but as her children grow, covering family needs has become harder. So Lala is requesting a loan to expand her activities and purchase more sheep. With your help, Lala can get ahead.

loans.use: Purchase 15 sheep and fodder

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en: Theresa is a very hardworking woman. She is 37 years old and a widow with 3 children. She sells cosmetics and hair extensions at retail prices to her customers. With these combined businesses, she is able to meet the basic needs of her family. She has been in this business for a long time. She is requesting a loan amount of 80,000 NGN to purchase more cosmetics to sell. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to make more profits during this season. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics to sell.

loans.name: Mrs. Sorth Shem Village Bank Group

texts.en: The village bank loan consists of thirteen people who all live in Veal Kandal village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sorth S. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a farmer who owns 1 hectar of land to cultivate rice. Now she faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money to hire workers to harvest the rice. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. Her husband, Mr. Auk Sam Ol, is a construction worker. This couple has eight children, three of whom are employed in a garment factory, two are construction workers, and the others are enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To hire workers to harvest rice.

loans.name: Zorig

texts.en:
M. Zorig is 37 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent called a ger. All three of his children, two sons and a daughter, attend a local secondary school.

Zorig operates a coal and firewood trading business in his town. He started his business in 2004 and has steadily built a consistent operation over the years. To supplement his earnings, he recently started a goods trading business which he conducts in the summertime. Since starting his business, Zorig has gained much experience as a businessman and has built positive relationships with both his customers and suppliers. Today, his working capital exceeds 1,000,000 tugrugs (~700 USD). Zorig is focused on growing his business in the future and says, "If I purchase an electrical saw I will greatly increase my work productivity." He is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase firewood and coal for his business.

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva's 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase firewood and coal

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is 59 years old, married, and has 3 children.

She sells crates of drinks at wholesale and retail prices to her customers. She has been in this business all her life and has the experience to ensure that she makes sales and keeps her customers. She plans to expand her business and increase her capital in the future. She is requesting a loan of 80,000 NGN to purchase more crates of drinks to sell.

She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Sok Khen Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Fifteen people, who all live in Veal Kandal Village in Kandal Province, make up the Village Bank Group. Mrs. Sok K. is the Village Bank President. She selects the members of the group, but they will all use the loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Sok K. is a farmer who owns one hectare of land on which she cultivates rice to earn a living. On this plantation, she faces an obstacle because her field has infertile soil. Thus, she decided to request a loan to buy fertilizers that will support the rice field and make her crops more productive.

Mrs. Sok K. is a 63-year-old widow with a child who is employed in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers

loans.name: Peterscott

texts.en:
Peterscott is 42 years old and married with four children, two of whom are attending school. He is a water vendor in the Kayole area of Nairobi. He's been in business for over three years and has three employees. He also earns some income as a caretaker. He requested his first loan from Faulu for Kes. 30,000 to buy handcarts and jerry cans. 

He describes himself as hardworking and ambitious and says that he hopes to increase his current business and expand into farming. In the future, he hopes to be a big farmer.

loans.use: Buy a handcart & jerry cans

loans.name: Victor

texts.en: Victor is 29 years old and married with three children, two of whom are attending school. He has a welding business in Nairobi. He's been in business since 2003 and has three employees. He requested this loan from Faulu for Kes. 30,000 to buy a cylinder of gas, two regulators, welding rods, and sheets. Since joining Faulu, Victor says he has been able to improve his business.

loans.use: Buy welding accessories

loans.name: Shola

texts.en:
Shola is a LAPO client. He is 41 years old, married, and has 4 children.

He has a photo studio and has been in this business for a long time. He hopes to expand his business in the future. He is requesting a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more film and a digital camera.

He thanks all kiva lenders. This is the high season for his business and he hopes to make more profits.

loans.use: To purchase more film and a digital camera

loans.name: Bosede

texts.en: Bosede is a LAPO client. She sells drinks and groceries at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to own a super market in the future. She is 45 years old, married with 4 children. She has been in this business for 6 years. She is requesting a loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more drinks and groceries to sell. She says thank you to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and groceries to sell

loans.name: Jargal

texts.en:
M. Jargal operates a business with his wife making gold and silver products in his town. He is 37 years old and lives with his wife in a house in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. He designs and produces a variety of jewelry including rings and bracelets. Jargal started his business in 1995 after working as a jewelry decorator. Now he both produces the gold and silver items and attaches stones and other decorative pieces. Jargal has grown his business steadily over the years and has a stable operation today. His earnings have enabled him to build a new home and buy a car for his family. Jargal has many plans for the future and hope to continue his success. He hopes to soon begin buying his gold and silver from the local markets in order to cut his costs. The mobile sellers he now uses are becoming too costly. He says, "With my future earnings, my wife and I plan to buy an apartment." Jargal is requesting a 1,950,000 tugrug loan to purchase raw materials for his business.

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva's 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase materials to make jewelry

loans.name: Mr. Pon Korng Village Bank Group

texts.en: The twelve people together requesting this village bank loan live in Veal Kandal village in Kandal province.  They will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes. Mr. Pon K. is the president of the village bank loan group. He is a construction worker and his wife, Mrs. Touch Van, is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she grows rice and vegetables. She needs some fertilizer to support the rice field but she does not have enough money. Thus, Mr. Pon K. decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed and fertilizer to support the rice field. He is 46 years old and the father of two children, one of whom is a commune assistant while the other stays at home to do housework.

loans.use: To buy rice seed and fertilizer.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is 35 years old and married with three children, two of whom are in school. She has a dressmaking and tailoring shop where she sells school uniforms, and suits for men and women. She's been in this business for 20 years and also earns some income from small-scale farming. She says that her business is busy and that she mainly sells to low-income earners. She successfully repaid a previous loan from Faulu for Kes. 20,000 and requested this loan for Kes. 30,000 to buy more material to make clothing. 

She describes herself as dedicated to her business, and through training at Faulu, she has learned to keep proper records so that she can check her losses and increase her profits. In the future, she hopes to have a wholesale business.

loans.use: Add stock of material

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en: Paulina is 42 years old and married with five children. Her husband is a government worker. She sells cooking oil and foodstuffs at retail prices to her customers. She has been in her business for a long time. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She is requesting a loan of 80,000 nairas to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Ebun

texts.en:
Ebun is a LAPO client. She sells sarongs of various colors and sizes. She hopes to own a fashion home in the future. This is the high season for sales and she hopes to make more profits during this season. She is 36 years old and married with a child. She has been in her business for a long time. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 nairas to purchase more sarongs to sell. 
She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Norovpil

texts.en:
M. Norovpil lives with her four children in Arkhangai province, Mongolia in a ger, a traditional nomadic tent. Her two sons and two daughters attend a local secondary school.  Norovpil manages a meat and livestock trading business in her town. She started her business in 2000 with 50,000 tugrugs (~35 USD) in capital.  Over the years, she has gained experience and her working capital now exceeds 500,000 tugrugs (~350 USD).  Norovpil has many plans for the future and says, "I hope to purchase a truck."  She is requesting a 500,000 tugrug (~350 USD) loan to purchase meat for her business. 
-----------------------------

loans.use: Purchase meat.

loans.name: Dominic

texts.en: Dominic is 33 years old and married with three children, aged one through ten. He has a small retail business and also earns some income through small-scale farming. He has successfully completed three loans through Faulu and is now requesting a loan for Kes. 35,000 to add more stock. In the future, he hopes to grow his business and own a hardware store.

loans.use: Add stock

loans.name: Mrs. Sopheng Pok Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Nineteen people who live in the Ta Reab Doun Sar village in Kandal make up this village bank loan.  Sopheng P. was selected by the members to serve as bank president.  

They will use their individual loans for different purposes.  Sopheng is a good housewife. Her husband, Dun Narith, is employed with a company. The couple has five children who are enrolled in the local schoO.. 

They face an obstacle because they do not have enough money to buy study materials for their children.  In order to deal with this problem, Sopheng decided to ask for a loan.

loans.use: Buy study materials for their children.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Amgalan

texts.en:
B. Amgalan is 42 years old and lives with her husband and 17-year-old-son in Arkhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent called a "ger". Her son currently attends a local secondary school. Amgalan operates a consumer goods trading business at a local trading center in her town with the help of her husband. Her husband also operates a taxi service in the evenings to supplement their income. Amgalan started her business in 2007 with working capital of 500,000 tugrugs (approximately 350 USD). She has quickly grown her business over the last two years and has built a strong customer base. Today, her working capital exceeds 1,500,000 tugrugs (approximately 1050 USD). Amgalan hopes to build on her experience in the future and says, "I want to expand my business and have my own shop." She is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (approximately 700 USD) loan to import clothes from China to sell in her business.

loans.use: To import clothes from China

loans.name: Muthama

texts.en:
Muthama is 24 years old and married. He has a business called Caltex Shop & Super Primacy Kinyozi where he sells household goods and operates a salon and kinyozi (barbershop). He's been in business for five years and also earns some income from small-scale farming. He was previously employed at Coca-Cola Company. He requested this loan from Faulu for Kes. 20,000 to buy stock of wheat flour and cooking fat, and to start a new kinyozi. 

He says that he is committed to his business and that in the future, he hopes to buy a bigger piece of land and employ ten people in his business.

loans.use: Add stock

loans.name: Idowu

texts.en: Idowu is a LAPO client. She sells kerosene at retail prices to her customers. She has one tank that she uses to store her kerosene. She hopes to sell kerosene at wholesale prices to her customers in the future. She is 38 years old and married with a child. Her husband is an engineer. She has been in this business for 5 years. She is requesting the loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more kerosene to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene to sell

loans.name: Tugs

texts.en:
M. Tugs lives in a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, called a "ger", in Arkhangai province in central Mongolia. She operates a small clothing production business in her town. Tugs started her clothing business in 2007 after working at an animal hospital for several years. At first, her working capital was 200,000 tugrugs (approximately 140 USD), but she has quickly gained experience, stabilized her business and become well established in the local business community. Her many customers appreciate her business for the good quality and stylish clothes she makes. Today, her working capital exceeds 1,500,000 tugrugs (approximately 1050 USD). Tugs is working hard to continue her success and says, "I want to save enough money to provide for my grandson." She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrugs (approximately 1400 USD) loan to purchase fabrics and other materials for her business.

loans.name: Fumilayo

texts.en: Fumilayo is 25 years old and married with a child. She sells eggs. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. She assists her husband in the family. She is very hardworking and she makes sure she has food on the table everyday through her hard work. She plans to add livestock sales to her business. She is requesting a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more eggs and livestock. With this kind of business, she hopes to increase her earnings in the long run and be able to provide better for her children's education. She says thank you to all kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more eggs to sell

loans.name: Samba

texts.en:
T. Samba lives in Uvurkhangai province in central Mongolia with her 15-year-old grandson. They live together in a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent called a "ger". Samba operates a consumer goods trading business out of a small shipping container in her town. She imports products such as clothes twice a month from China to supply her business. Samba started her business in 2002 after working as a hairdresser for several years. At first, she rented a stall at the local market to conduct her business. After several years of steady growth, Samba used her earnings to purchase the shipping container in 2005. Operating from the container has allowed her to grow her business further and she is now looking for more ways to increase her earnings. Samba has much hope for the future and says, "I am working hard to save for my grandchild's education." She is requesting a 2,500,000 tugrug (approximately 1750 USD) loan to purchase a variety of clothes from China.

loans.name: Mrs. Son Hem Village Bank Group

texts.en: A village bank loan which consists of fourteen people, is located in Ta Reab Doun Sar village in Kandal province. All the members will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Son H. is the village bank president. She and her husband, Mr. H. Keang, are farmers who own a plot of land to grow lotus. In this business, they do not have enough money to expend for growing. Thus, Mrs. Son H. decided to request a loan to grow lotus. She is 39 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is a construction worker while the others are enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To request a loan to grow lotus.

loans.name: Baasan

texts.en:
O. Baasan is 51 years old and lives with his wife and 22-year-old son in an apartment in Dornogobi province, Mongolia. His youngest son, Altanshagai, currently attends college and his wife is a retired doctor. Basaan manages a taxi service in his town. He started his business in 2001 by renting a car from his friend. After growing his business, he used his savings and a loan to purchase his own car. After repaying his loan, he took out another loan to make repairs and improve his car. He has used these improvements to further grow his business and has proven himself as a trustworthy borrower. Baasan is working hard to achieve his future goals and provide for his family and son's education. He says, "All of my older children are on their own and live happy and successful lives. All I want is to educate my youngest son so he can achieve the same life as his siblings. I want to expand my business and hope to open a tourism company in the future." Baasan is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (approximately 1050 USD) loan to pay his son's tuition fees.

loans.use: To pay his son's tuition fees.

loans.name: Mrs. Makara Shum Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of sixteen people, who all live in Ta Reab DoU. Sar village in Kandal province. Mrs. Makara S. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. In this plantation, she has a problem because she does not have enough money to grow lotus to earn income. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. Her husband, Mr. U. Vuth, is a fisherman. He is also a cook who is hired by the villagers to cook during weddings, ceremonies, parties, and so on. This couple has three children who are attending the local school.

loans.use: To grow lotus to earn income.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: To earn a living, Mary sells frozen foods like turkey, chicken and fish at retail prices to her customers. This is the high season for sales and she hopes to meet the demands of her customers. She is 37 years old and married with 3 children. Her husband is an estate surveyor. She has been in business for 2 years. She is requesting the loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more frozen foods to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen foods to sell

loans.name: George Doliro Group

texts.en:
George D. is from the village of Calabayan Minanga, Angadanan, Isabela. He is 33 years old. George is the group leader of a 12-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is George D..

George is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, George owns and operates a business venture in the services sector. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating a welding shop/steel fabrication. George has been engaged in his business for over 3 years, and earns approximately Php 12,000 a month from these activities.

In 2006, George joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. George has successfully repaid a previous loans  from ASKI. George is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by George from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to expand services provided

loans.name: Iyabo

texts.en: Iyabo sells wine and gin at retail prices to her customers. She is 45 years old and married with 5 children. Her husband is an engineer. She hopes to be a major wine distributor in her community in the future. She has been in this business for a long time. She is requesting a loan amount of 60,000 NGN to purchase more gin and wine to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more gin and wine to sell.

loans.name: Rodel

texts.en:
Rodel C. is from the village of Ibung, Villa Verde, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 48 years old. Rodel is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Rodel owns and operates a business venture in the services sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income from the business comes primarily from providing motorcycle transport to local community members. Rodel has been engaged in this business for over 4 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Rodel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rodel is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rodel from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small business entrepreneurs.
