loans.name: Sodnom

texts.en:
Sodnom J. is 33 years old and lives with his wife and two sons in Uvurkhangai province in central Mongolia. He and his family live together in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a "ger". His oldest son is 17 years old and attends a local secondary school and his youngest will soon start kindergarten. Sodnom operates a transportation service and flour and rice trading business in his town. He transports people and goods from his province to Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city. In Ulaanbaatar, he purchases rice and flour which he transports back to his province to sell. His wife assists in the business and sells the products when her husband is traveling. Sodnom started his business in 2008 and has made much progress in his first year of operation. He has many plans for the future and says, "With stable business operations, my wife and I are planning to expand our flour and rice trading business and hope to begin selling a wide variety of grocery products". Sodnom is requesting a 3,500,000 tugrug (~2,500 USD) loan to purchase flour and rice to sell in his business.

loans.name: Surmaahorloo

texts.en:
Surmaahorloo O. is 27 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in Uvurkhangai province in central Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Her oldest son, Bilguunsaikhan, is seven years old and attends a local secondary school. Her youngest, Turbold, has not yet reached school age. Surmaahorloo operates a dairy product selling business in her town. She started her business in 2000 by renting a stall at the local market to sell her products. After years of successful business operations, she used her savings to build a small shop in 2007. Having her own shop has been very positive for her business and she has built a great reputation among her many customers. Surmaahorloo attributes her success to her good accounting skills. She has many plans for the future and says, "I want to expand my business and build an addition on to my shop." She is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (~1,050 USD) loan to purchase dairy products to sell in her business.

loans.use: To purchase dairy products to sell.

loans.name: Iyabo

texts.en: Iyabo sells kerosene at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to be a major kerosene distributor in future. She is 37 years old and married with 3 children. Her husband is a carpenter and he also supports the household. She has been in this business for a long time. She sells for long hours to enable her to put food on her table to feed her immediate family members. She is requesting a loan amount of 60,000 NGN to purchase more kerosene to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene to sell.

loans.name: Claudia Corazon

texts.en:
Claudia Corazon M. is from the village of Ibung Villa Verde, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 45 years old. Claudia Corazon is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business venture in the arts sector operating a handicraft business. While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling specialty handicrafts to tourists and local community members. Claudia Corazon has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Claudia Corazon joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts. This loan will be the first loan taken out by her from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small business entrepreneurs.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts

loans.name: Atar

texts.en:
Atar J. is currently in the business of selling charcoal at home and is requesting a loan to buy more bags of charcoal to sell.  Atar is 25 years old and is married. Her husband is a teacher. She has two children; neither go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a hardware shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: buy more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Tsetseg

texts.en: Tsetseg P. is 53 years old and lives in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. She lives alone in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. She currently operates a meat trading business in her town. Tsetseg started her business in 1996 with capital of 200,000 tugrugs (~140 USD) after working as a security guard for several years. Tsetseg has steadily grown her business over the years and has gained much experience as a businesswoman. Today, her working capital exceeds 350,000 tugrugs (~250 USD). Tsetseg is a very hardworking person and is known by her friends for her good character. She hopes to work well into the future and is planning to soon expand her business. She says, "I plan to work as long as I am able. Operating my business brings great joy to my life." She is requesting a 300,000 tugrugs (~210 USD) loan to purchase a variety of meats to sell in her business.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of meats to sell.

loans.name: Bose

texts.en: Bose is 37 years old and married with 2 children. Her husband is an engineer. She sells electrical materials at the front of her house in Ibadan, Oyo State. She is a friendly woman and she uses her friendliness to attract more customers to her stall. She is very happy because she does not have to pay stall rent. She has been in this business for a long time. She is requesting a loan in the amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more electrical materials to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more electrical materials to sell

loans.name: Elnora

texts.en:
Elnora D. is from the village of Ibung Villa Verde, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 42 years old. Elnora is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Elnora owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Elnora has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Elnora joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elnora has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from ASKI. Elnora is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Elnora from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Brigida

texts.en:
Brigida B. is from the village of Ibung Villa Verde, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 60 years old. Brigida is married and has 7 adult-aged children. To make a living, Brigida is engaged in running a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Brigida has been engaged in her business for over 5 years now.

In 2006, Brigida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Brigida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 28,000 PHP from ASKI. Brigida is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Brigida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About ASKI:

loans.name: Mey

texts.en:
Mey L. was born in 1959 and is the good mother of three children. All three of them are out of school and currently work in the garment factory.

Mey is an animal raiser who has four years' experience in this business. She also distills wine, and she feeds the leftovers from the process to her animals. Her husband assists her with the business activities (he appears in the picture).

Because raising animals is the primary method for Mey to raise income, she is asking for capital to help her business be more efficient and successful.

loans.use: Capital to help her business be more efficient and successful

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline T. is from the village of Ibung Villa Verde, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 46 years old. Evangeline is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Evangeline owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from preparing and selling barbecue pork and chicken for sale. Evangeline has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Evangeline joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evangeline has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell. Evangeline is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Evangeline from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About ASKI:

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary has a printing machine that she uses in her business. She is 50 years old and married with one child. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes to expand her business in the future.

She is requesting a loan of 60,000 NGN to purchase more printing materials. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more printing materials

The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Flordeliza has been engaged in her business for over 4 years.

In 2007, Flordeliza joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Jane owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years.
