payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Vilma Del Carmen

texts.es: Vilma del Carmen C. de 48 años de edad reside en Tacuba en el departamento de Ahuachapán, vive con su esposo, junto al cual trabajan arduamente día con día para poder seguir adelante y poder vivir una vida digna. Vilma comercializa ropa para hombres y mujeres, la cual la vende en las calles de Tacuba. A pesar del peligro de vender su ropa en las calles, ella se esfuerza por vender lo más posible cada día, es por esta razón por la cual ella solícita un préstamo a través del cual pueda tener la capacidad de poder comprar más ropa y poder aumentar sus ventas.
texts.en:
48-year old Vilma del Carmen C. and her husband live in Tacuba in Ahuachapán department. They both work hard every day in order to get ahead and live a decent life. Vilma sells men’s and women’s clothing in the streets of Tacuba. Despite the danger of selling in the street, she puts in a lot of effort to sell as much as possible every day. For this reason she is asking for a loan to buy more clothing so that she can increase her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy clothing

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet S. is a very wonderful businesswoman rendering tailoring services since the year 2006. She is 35 years of age and living with her spouse. S. Juliet is blessed with four children all going to school and she aso looks after two dependents, one who is schooling. She is using the loan to purchase clothing material for designing different clothes for sale. She says with the loan, she has learned to think very fast as well work very hard to meet her target. She wishes to obtain a plot of land in Ntungamo town and build a house in her name, S., so that she can remain proud of herself and the Kiva loan the rest of her life.

loans.use: To purchase clothing material

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy O. is from the village of Siempre Viva Sur, Mallig. She is 52 years old. Nancy is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Nancy owns & operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Nancy has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nancy joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nancy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baking equipment. Nancy is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Nancy from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Vera Alicia

texts.es: Vera Alicia H. D. E. D. 30 años D. edad, resiD. en el departamento D. Ahuachapán, vive junto a su esposo y sus tres hijos, todos menores D. edad. Ella posee una venta D. tortillas y pupusas en su casa D. habitación, negocio el cual le permite ayudarle a su esposo con los gastos del hogar, sobre todo con los gastos D. los estudios D. sus pequeños hijos. Vera solícita un préstamo a través del cual podrá comprar maíz, frijoles y arroz, producto con el cual pueD. realizar las pupusas y las tortillas, comida la cual se venD. mucho en El Salvador debido a que forma parte D. la dieta salvadoreña, sobre todo en el caso D. las tortillas la cuales se consumen diariamente.
texts.en:
Vera Alicia is 30 years old, resides in Ahuachapán Department, and lives with her husband and their 3 children who are minors. She sells tortillas, both regular and stuffed, from her house. The business enables her to help her husband with household expenses, especially with the costs of educating their small children. >p> Vera is soliciting a loan to buy corn, beans and rice, products that are necessary to make regular and stuffed tortillas. Such items sell well in El Salvador since they are important in the Salvadoran diet. This is especially true of tortillas, which are consumed daily.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO BUY CORN, BEANS, AND RICE TO MAKE REGULAR AND STUFFED TORTILLAS TO SELL

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase retail stock such as sugar, salt, maize flour, beans, ground nuts, drinks, etc

loans.name: Nanjid

texts.en:
G. Nanjid is 50 years old and lives with his wife and two sons in Gobi-Altai province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a "ger". His oldest son, Batbayar, is a University student and his youngest, Amartuvshin, is in high school.

Nanjid operates a vegetable and rye-flour trading business in his town with the help of his wife. He purchases his flour in bulk from suppliers, but grows and harvests the vegetables that he sells. Nanjid started his business in 2004 after conducting a firewood trading business for the previous two years. He has built a consistent operation over the years and his business continues to grow quickly today.

Nanjid has many plans for the future and hopes to grow his vegetable business as well as begin selling new products. He says, "I plan to plant more fields next year in order to increase my output. I must increase my sales so I can pay my children's tuition fees." He is requesting a 800,000 MNT loan to purchase grass and begin selling it to herders. About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest micro-finance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: to purchase grass and begin selling it to herders

loans.name: Mon

texts.en: Mrs. Mon L. is a good homemaker who cares for the children and does housework. Mon L. currently depends on the income from her husband’s work. He provides a well-digging service. His skill is digging wells by hand, and he has been working at it for years. He earns $7 a day to buy food for his family. Mon L.’s husband has been very busy at his business due to there being many clients who need him to dig their well, but he is still lacking materials to perform his service. Therefore, Mon L. requested a loan to purchase more digging materials. Note: Mon L.’s husband is pictured above.

loans.use: To purchase more digging materials

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida T. is from the village of Aurora. She is 41 years old. Zenaida is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Zenaida owns & operates a business planting & harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Zenaida has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Zenaida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zenaida is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Zenaida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Ochir

texts.en:
Ochir B. is 26 years old and lives with his wife in Uvurkhangai province, Mongolia. They live together in a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, called a “ger.”

Ochir operates a small pet shop as well as a taxi service in his town with the help of his wife. His wife is mainly responsible for managing the pet shop where they sell many animals including dogs, cats, and fish, as well as a variety of animal products.

Ochir uses the family car to operate his taxi service. He started operating as a taxi driver in 2005 by transporting people to and from his province and the surrounding provinces. After growing his business, he used his savings to open the pet shop.

Ochir and his wife have many plans for their businesses in the future. They hope to soon expand the rented space in which they now operate the pet shop. Ochir is a very hardworking businessman and is known for his good character.

He says, "I want to have a large pet store in the future." He is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase animals and expand his pet shop.

About XacBank

XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team:
http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:
http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All§ors[]=All®ions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.use: To purchase animals and expand his pet shop.

loans.name: Aylen

texts.en:
Aylen D. lives in the village of Brgy. Sibucao, San Enrique, Negros Occidental. She is 38 years old, married, with 3 school-age children. Her husband used to be a baker, but now he helps Aylen run their business.

When her husband was earning a salary as a baker, Aylen stringently allocated the income on their household's needs. But she realized that as her children grew, their expenses would also increase and soon her husband's income would not be sufficient.

This encouraged her to join NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001. She used the new capital to start a food vending business, selling food within her community and in the neighboring villages. She also put up a "sari-sari" or general store to ensure that she would have a regular daily income. The business performance was so good that the couple decided it would be more lucrative for her husband to manage their general store than earn a monthly salary as a baker. 

As their business experience widened, they also took on new opportunities like selling vegetables. Now they earn a monthly income of 15,000 PHP, which is quite enough for the current needs of their family including the education of the children.

Aylen used her previous loan of 21,000 PHP as additional capital for her businesses. Now Aylen will use her 18th cycle loan of 22,000 PHP as working capital for her general store. Income from it will be used for house improvements.

About NWTF

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital for her general store.

loans.name: Has

texts.en:
Has P. is married, but divorced her husband when her four children were very young. Today, three of her children are employed; two are garment factory workers and the other one is a garage keeper.

Has P. sells meatballs and beef to earn a living. She retails her products that she buys in bulk from her wholesale supplier.

Has P. also finds it hard traveling anywhere because she has no vehicle for her travel needs. Thus she is requesting a loan from Kiva to buy an old motorcycle for her travel needs.

loans.use: To buy an old motorcycle.

loans.name: Sarantuya

texts.en:
A. Sarantuya is 42 years old and lives with her husband and three sons in Huvsgul province, Mongolia. Her middle son currently attends university and her youngest attends a local secondary school. She and her family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a "ger". Sarantuya operates a shoe-making business in her town with the help of her husband. She started her business in 1990 and has built a stable and successful business over the years. She is a very motivated businesswoman and works hard to support her family and her community. In 2008 she was named "Volunteer Leader of the Year" in her community by the local branch of World Vision, an international development organization, for making shoes for handicapped children. Sarantuya hopes to continue her success in the future and says, "My business enables me to provide for my children's education and improve their quality of life." She is requesting a 300,000 tugrug loan to purchase materials used in making shoes. About XacBank: XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.
To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team.
To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase materials used in making shoes

loans.name: Catalina

texts.en:
Catalina M. is from the city of Maloro, Tangub City. She is 41 years old, is married, and has five adult children. Catalina owns and operates a business running a food stall, tending a canteen near the school. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Catalina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Nena

texts.en: She's a 69 year-old widow who continues to earn her own living because she wants to stay independent and also continue to help her children establish their own lives. Nena G. has been a widow since 2006 and lives in the village of Barangay Palaka, Pulupandan, Negros Occidental. Her husband's death was a great loss to the family and since all of her seven children are grown up with their own families, Nena wanted to remain independent and be able to earn a living so that she could provide for her old age. Years ago Nena put up her general store to help her husband to raise income of the family to support its needs, especially as they had seven children. She said when she started her business, she found it quite hard to look after the needs of her children and at the same time handle the business, but she coped with all the hardships with much determination. Because of Nena’s hard work, her business grew, and she joined NWTF Project Dungganon (NWTF-PD) in 1998 so that she could access more capital for her business. With new capital infusion, she expanded her product offerings to include guinamos (shrimp paste) which is a popular flavoring and dish in the Philippines. She also traveled to other towns to sell her shrimp paste. Her guinamos was so popular that she now has regular customers, some from other towns, who prefer to buy their shrimp paste exclusively from her. Now, Nena earns a monthly income of PHP 18,000 and she saves most of this for her future security and for emergencies. She sometimes uses some of it to help out her children. Nena’s previous loan of Php 15,000 was used in her business as additional capital and it was repaid within her loan term in full and on-time, maintaining her good standing as an NWTF-PD member. Now she is borrowing Php 20,000 for her 15th loan to be utilized for her general store and her guinamos business. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her general store

loans.name: Koeum

texts.en: Koeum S. is a widower man and father of three children. Two of his daughters are merchandise sellers in the market, while the other one is married and has started a new family. To earn a living, Koeum S. owns an old motorbike that he uses to provide a taxi service. Recently, his existing taxi is often broken which affects his income. Because of that, Koeum S. decided to seek a loan of $400 to be used to replace his broken taxi.

loans.use: To replace his broken taxi

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en: Nothing is impossible when you believe in yourself and you are wiling to work hard, courageously persevere and love what you do. This is what Elsie M. is doing to attain her dreams with the help of NWTF-Project Dungganon. Elsie is 40 years old, and married to Leonilo, who helps her run their scrap business. They have 4 children who are between 10 and 18 years old. 2 are in college and the younger 2 are in high school and grade school. The family lives in Prk. Kulitis, Barrio Dos Hermanas, Talisay City, Negros Occidental. It is one of Elsie's most cherished dreams that her children be able to finish college and have their own stable and comfortable livelihoods when they grow up. Concerned for her children's future, Elsie joined NWTF Project Dungganon in 2002 so that she could increase her capital in their scrap business. With the added buying capability, she was able to buy back more recyclables like scrap iron, bottles, plastic, etc. Now she is earning approximately PHP 30,000 per month from her business operations. From this she was able to buy a motorcycle and a small pickup truck for faster delivery of her scrap materials. She has also happily set aside some amount for her children's education. Elsie's previous loan of PHP 15,000 was used as revolving capital for her scrap business and now that she's paid that off, she is borrowing the same amount so that she could continue maintaining her scrap buyback levels and be able to sell the scrap in volume, earning a neat profit. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon(a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional Working Capital

loans.name: Benkan Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benkan sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 40 ans et 2 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de MARKA COUNKO, sous préfecture de FANA, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parentés. Elles exercent le commerce d’articles divers il y’a un peu longtemps de cela. 
Ces femmes collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire et le prêt précédent a été correctement remboursé. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, une grande quantité de poissons fumés et d’articles divers tels que les habillements et les produits de premières nécessités. Le poisson fumé est acheté en gros à Mopti, les habillements et les autres articles sont achetés au Burkina et à Bamako et le tout est revendu sur place dans le marché de  MARKA COUNKO à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 35 000FCFA par mois. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the Benkan group are married women with an average age of 40 years and on average 2 children. With their husband and children they live in large traditional families and reside in the village of MARKA COUNKO, sous-prefecture of FANA, in the region of KOULIKORO, Republic of Mali.

They met each other through neighborhood and kinship links. They have been selling various items for quite some time.

These women work in collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to perpetuate their money-making activity. This is their second group loan and the previous loan was fully reimbursed.

With this loan they wish to buy large quantities of smoked fish and various items such as clothing, and basic need products. The smoked fish is bought wholesale in Mopti, the clothing and other articles in Burkina and in Bamako. They resell everything on the market place in MARKA COUNKO to customers who are women and men.

They are planning to each make an average monthly profit of 35, 000 FCFA. The profits are reinvested in part in their activity and the other part goes to the daily family expenses.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various items

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Djekafo de l’association Yenkadi  sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 42 ans et 4 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de MARKA COUNKO, sous préfecture de FANA, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage,  de parentés et exercent le commerce  de produits alimentaires. 
Ces femmes collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. 
Elles sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, beaucoup de condiments alimentaires en gros et du lait. Les condiments  sont achetés à Bamako, le lait est acheté avec les peulhs du village et tous les produits sont revendus sur place dans le marché de MARKA COUNKO à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 15 000     FCFA par mois. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
Members of Djekafo group of Yenkadi association are married women, having an average age of 42 years and 4 children. They live in big traditional families with their husbands and children and reside in MARKA COUNKO village within the FANA prefecture of KOULIKORO region of the Republic of Mali. They know each other through their family relations and neighborhood ties and they trade in foodstuffs. These women are working with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution with the aim of making durable their lucrative business activities. They are on their third group loan and all preceding loans have been repaid correctly. With this loan, they hope to buy much food ingredients in bulk and some milk. The ingredients are bought in Bamako, the milk from Fulanis of the village and all products are retailed right in the MARKA COUNKO market to a clientele made up of male and female. They expect to make an average monthly profit of 15 000 FCFA each. On one hand, the profits are reinvested in the business and in the daily family expenses, on the other hand.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food ingredients and some milk

loans.name: Amelia Salomao Chambrando

texts.pt:
Amélia Salomão Chambrando N. nasceu na Província de Inhambane, tem 30 anos de idade, solteira e mãe de 2 filhos gémeos de 7 anos de idade a estudar. Fez somente 7ª classe e não continuou por falta de condições. Vive na casa própria com seus filhos, não sustenta mais ninguém. 

Saiu de Inhambane com os pais ainda criança para cidade de Maputo devido a guerra de destabilização. Tem um negocio próprio há mais de 2 anos sem empregada e trabalha cerca de 10 horas por dia. Vende peixe e recargas de telemóveis e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 1.500.00mt por dia que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa cerca de 400.00mt através de Xitique (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa).

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de uma vizinha e este é o seu 1º empréstimo no valor de 8.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (peixe, recargas para telemóveis, batata e outros) para aumentar o volume de negocio e ganhar dinheiro razoável para garantir toda assistência e educação aos seus filhos.
 
No futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para construir uma mini mercearia na sua própria casa.
texts.en:
Amélia Salomão Chambrando was born in the Inhambane province. She is 30 years old, and a single mother of twins, who are 7 years old and going to school. She did only up to the 7th grade and stopped studying for a lack of conditions to do so. She lives in her own house with her children and does not support anyone else. She left Inhambane with her parents when she was still a child to the city of Maputo, due to the destabilization war. She has her own business for more than 2 years, with no employees, and works about 10 hours a day. She sells fish and mobile phone credit recharges, being able to earn around MZN 1,500.00 a day. She applies her earnings on the house expenses and saves about MZN 400.00 through Xitique (traditional rotational savings system). She has never had loans from other banks. She learned about Hluvuku through a neighbor. This is her first loan, of MZN 8,000.00, with which she intends to buy products (fish, mobile recharge cards, potatoes and others) in order to increase her business and earn enough money to guarantee support and education to her children. In the future, she intends to request more loans to build a small grocery market in her house.

Translated from Portuguese by Giovanna Fernandes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy and Selling of products (fish and others)

loans.name: Nan

texts.en: Mrs. Nan T. is 36 years old, and sells fish and some vegetables to earn a living. Nan T. is married and is blessed with two young children, who are dependent on her income. Her husband is pictured here, who helps her in selling her items. In the past, Nan T. always hired a taxi at a high price for transporting her items to the market. She now wants to own a vehicle to use as transportation and is asking for a Kiva loan to purchase a used motorbike.

loans.use: To purchase a used motorbike

loans.name: Rosa

texts.pt:
Rosa C. nasceu no Distrito de Namaacha, fronteira com a Suazilândia, Província de Maputo, tem 51 anos de idade, solteira e mãe de 7 filhos de 30, 27, 23, 22 e 17 anos de idade, apenas o mais velho já não vai a escola. Fez somente 4ª classe e não continuou porque a mãe levou a ela para Republica da Africa do sul quando perdeu o pai. Vive na casa própria com seus filhos e sustenta um neto que vive com ela. 

Saiu de Namaacha para Boane em 2007 com os seus filhos, depois de ter comprado uma residência, porque onde vivia a casa era alugada. Tem um negocio próprio ha mais de 17 anos, não tem empregado, trabalha desde as 08 ate as 17h todos os dias. Vende mais refrescos e bebidas onde consegue um rendimento de cerca de 1.000.00mt por dia que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa cerca de 200.00mt através de Xitique (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa) numa base semanal.

Já teve empréstimos na Associação GueGue Gue (cooperativa de credito) mais tarde decidiu não continuar por motivos diversos.
Conheceu a Hluvuku através de vizinhos e este é o seu 1º empréstimo no valor de 8.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (refrescos, bebidas e outros) para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria no seu estabelecimento e subir o seu rendimento nas vendas.
 
Futuramente pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para construir capoeiras para criação de frangos de corte e concluir a sua obra.
texts.en:
Rosa C. was born in the district of Namaacha, which is on the border with Swaziland, in the province of Maputo. She is 51 and is the single mother of 7 children who are 30, 27, 23, 23, and 17. Only the oldest one isn't in school. She only studied through 4th grade and didn't continue because her mother took her to South Africa when she lost her father. She lives in her own home with her children and supports a grandchild that lives with her.

She left Namaacha for Boane in 2007 with her children after having purchased a house because the one where she used to live was rented. She has had her own business for 17 years and has never had an employee. She works from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. every day. She sells soft drinks and alcoholic beverages and makes a montly income of 1,000 meticais per day, which she applies to her home's expenses. She saves 200 meticais on a weekly basis through a traditional rotating savings system known as Xitique.

She has already had loans with the GueGue Gue Association (a credit cooperative) and later decided not to continue with them for various reasons. She became familiar with Hluvuku through neighbors. This is her first loan in the amount of 8,000 meticais, which she will use to purchase products (soft drinks, alcoholic drinks, etc.) to increase the quantity of her merchandise in her business to increase her sales.

In the future, she hopes to request more loans to construct coops to raise chickens to butcher and to finish building her home.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell products (soft drinks, beer, and other drinks)

loans.name: Djiguiya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Djiguiya sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 42 ans et 4  enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de MARKA COUNKO, sous préfecture de FANA, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à travers  des liens de voisinage et de parentés. Elles exercent le commerce d’articles divers depuis maintenant plusieurs années. 
Ces femmes collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. 
Elles sont à leur onzième prêt solidaire et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter,  80 sacs de charbon de bois et une grande quantité d’habillements et de chaussures en plastique. Le charbon de bois est acheté en détail dans les villages  environnants, l’habillement et les chaussures auprès des commerçants grossistes. 
Tous les produits sont  revendus sur place dans le marché de MARKA COUNKO  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 40 000F CFA par mois. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of Djiguiya group are married women having an average age of 42 years and 4 children. They live in big traditional family homes with their husbands and children and reside in the MARKA COUNKO village within the FANA prefecture of KOULIKORO region of the Republic of Mali. They got to know each other through their family ties and neighborhood relationship. They have been trading in various items for several years now. These women are working with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution with the aim of making durable their lucrative businesses. They are on their eleventh group loan and all preceding loans have been repaid correctly. With this loan, they expect to buy 80 bags of charcoal and a large quantity of clothes and synthetic shoes.The charcoal is bought in the surrounding villages and the clothes and shoes from wholesale shopkeepers. All the products are resold right in the MARKA COUNKO market to a clientele made up of male and female. They hope to make an average monthly profit of 40 000 FCFA each. On one hand, the profits are reinvested in the business and in the daily family expenses, on the other hand.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of miscelleneous items

loans.name: Nkodo 2 Mugagasana Joyce Group

texts.en: Joyce M. is a group representative, of forty years of age, carrying out livestock activity. She has been doing this business activity for over ten years. Because her animals could die due to the drought season, she is now using the loan to purchase more animals, feed, drugs, and so forth for livestock. She is a hard-working woman whose hopes are to raise her standards of living, educate her children and obtain other businesses for more income generation.

loans.use: To purchase animals and supplies for livestock.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase bulk supplies to sell.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose P. is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste at home and is requesting a loan to buy more groundnuts for making paste to sell.  Rose is 40 years old and is married to a policeman. She has 6 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a new house for her children and pay their school fees.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Buy groundnuts for making paste to sell.

loans.name: Port

texts.en:
Mr. Port M., age 36, is a construction foreman. He has many employees who help him to deliver his services. Port M. is married and three school-aged children. His wife, who appears with him in the photograph, is a chef for local wedding parties. 

Port M. has been very busy at his business because there being many customers who need him to build their houses, but he is still lacking the materials of construction. Because he doesn’t have money yet, he decided to ask a loan from Kiva through HKL to buy more materials so he can improve his services.

loans.use: To buy more materials for his construction business

loans.name: Jolidenw Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Jolidenw sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 33 ans et 3 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de MARKA COUNKO, sous préfecture de FANA, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à travers  des liens de voisinage et de parentés. Elles exercent les activités d’achat et de ventes de condiments alimentaires et la restauration il y’a un peu longtemps de cela. 
Ces femmes collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. 
Elles sont à leur onzième prêt solidaire et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires et du riz pour la restauration. Les condiments sont achetés en gros à Bamako et sont revendus en détail sur place à MARKA COUNKO et une partie est utilisée dans la restauration servant de nourriture pour les passagers. La composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 25 000F CFA par mois. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of group Jolidenw are married women having an average age of 33 years and 3 children. They live in big traditional family homes with their husbands and children. They reside in the village of MARKA COUNKO within the FANA prefecture, KOULIKORO region of the Republic of Mali. They know each other through family ties and neighborhood relationship. They have been in the business of buying and selling of food ingredients and catering for a little longer. These women work with Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution with the aim to making durable their lucrative businesses. They are on their eleventh group loan and all preceding loans have been repaid correctly. With this loan, they expect to buy large quantity of food ingredients and rice for the catering business. The ingredients are bought in bulk in Bamako and resold in bits right in MARKA COUMBO and a part is used in catering to serve passengers, comprised of male and female.They expect to make an average monthly profit of 25 000FCFA each. On one hand, the profits are reinvested in the business and in the daily family expenses , on the other hand.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food ingrdients and some rice

loans.name: Afrita Julio

texts.pt:
Afrita Júlio I. nasceu na cidade da Matola, Província de Maputo, tem 51 anos de idade, solteira e mãe de 4 filhos de 28, 26, 20, e 13 anos de idade, três destes vão a escola. Fez somente 6ª classe e não continuou por falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa própria com seus filhos e ainda sustenta a mãe e o pai que vivem com ela. 

Saiu da Matola para Distrito de Boane no bairro Xinonankila há mais de 10 anos com os seus filhos, depois de ter construído a sua residência. Trabalha numa serigrafia como encadernadora há mais de 4 anos, faz 8 horas de trabalho por dia e tem um salário mensal de 5.300.00mt que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum através de Xitique (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa).

Nunca teve empréstimos com outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de vizinhos que também são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu 2º empréstimo no valor de 16.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (chapas de zinco, pedra, areia e janelas) para dar continuidade com a construção da sua casa. O empréstimo anterior foi de 15.000.00mt para a mesma actividade.
 
No futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para concluir a sua casa, comprar mobiliário para melhor acomodar a sua família.
texts.en:
Afrita Júlio I. was born in Matola, Maputo Province, Mozambique. She is 51 years old and a single mother of four children ages 28, 26, 20 and 13, three of them students. She finished 6th grade but had to drop school due to lack of financial support. She lives in her own house with her children and supports her parents who also live with them. She left Matola to go to Boane more than 10 years ago with her children, after having built her home. She works at a serigraphy and makes 5.300,00MT (U$170) per month, money that she uses to cover her household expenses and save. This is her second loan and she's asking for 16.000,00MT (U$525) in order to buy construction supplies (zinc plates, rocks, sand and windows) to finish building her house. Her previous loan was used for the same purpose. In the future she would like to get other loans to finish building her house, buy furniture and better accomodate her large family.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction Supplies

loans.name: Nieta Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Nieta sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 42 ans et 5 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de MARKA COUNKO, sous préfecture de FANA, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à  travers des liens de voisinage et de parentés. Elles exercent le commerce d’articles divers il y’a un peu longtemps de cela. 
Ces femmes collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. 
Elles sont à leur sixième prêt solidaire et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, des tissus au Burkina, une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires et d’articles divers tels que le sucre, l’huile alimentaire, les boîtes de conserves. Ces produits sont achetés à Bamako et le tout est revendu sur place à MARKA COUNKO à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 20 000F CFA par mois. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of Nieta Group are all married women who, on average, are 42 years old and have five children. They live with their husband and children in large traditional families in the village of Marka Counko, subprefecture of Fana, in the region of Kolikoro of the Republic of Mali. They know each other through neighborhood and family links.

These women have been merchants of various articles for quite some time. They have joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to ensure the long-term success of their businesses. This is their sixth solidarity loan. They have repaid all their previous loans on schedule.

They will use this new loan to buy fabrics in Burkina Faso and also a large quantity of food condiments and various grocery articles such as sugar, vegetable oil and cans. They will buy these products in Bamako and retail them in Marka Counko to a clientele made up of women and men.

They expect to make an average monthly profit of 20,000 CFA francs each. They will reinvest part of their profit in their businesses and use part of it to contribute to the daily expenses of their families.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various articles

loans.name: Fozia

texts.en:
Fozia S. sells fresh vegetables in the market. She is requesting a loan to purchase bags of charcoal to sell. Fozia is 40 years old and married to a police officer. She has 6 children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay her children's school fees.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase bags of charcoal for sell

loans.name: Abilio

texts.pt:
Abílio T. nasceu na cidade da Matola, Província de Maputo, tem 53 anos de idade, casado e pai de 1 filho de 28 anos de idade que frequenta a escola. Abílio fez 9ª classe e não continuou por falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa própria com sua família, sustenta a mãe que vive com ela e ainda sua filha em despesas escolares e alimentares.

Nunca mudou do sítio onde vive, construiu uma nova residência ao lado da casa dos pais e vive com a sua família ate hoje. É negociante a tempo inteiro e dono do seu próprio negocio há mais de 25 anos, faz em media cerca de 10 horas por dia e tem um rendimento de cerca de 12.000.00mt por mês que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum no banco comercial BIM.

Já teve empréstimos com a cooperativa de crédito TCHUMA, mais tarde conheceu a Hluvuku através de vizinhos que também são clientes desta instituição e decidiu solicitar o seu 1º empréstimo. Este é o seu 3º empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (Cervejas, sumos, bebidas secas e refrescos) para aumentar a mercadoria do seu estabelecimento. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 9.000.00mt e 15.500.00mt todos para a mesma actividade.
 
No futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para ampliar o seu estaleiro e comprar uma viatura como meio de ajudar no transporte da sua mercadoria.
texts.en:
Abílio T. was born in the city of Matola, in the Maputo province. He is 53 years old, married and father of a 28 years old son who attends school. Abílio studied up to the 9th grade e did not continue due to lack of financial conditions. He lives in his own house with his family and supports his mother, who lives with him. He also pays his daughter's school and food expenses.

He has never moved from the place where he lives. He has built a new house beside his parents' house, and there is where he lives with his family today. He is a full-time trader, and the owner of his business for more than 25 years. He works in average 10 hours a day, and earns approximately MZN 12,000 a month. He uses his earning to pay for the house expenses and he also saves some money at the commercial bank BIM.

He has had loans from the credit union TCHUMA. Later on, he learned about Hluvuku through neighbors who are also clients of this institution and decided to request his first loan. This is his third loan, of MZN 15,000, with which he intends to buy products (beer, juice, dry beverages and soft drinks) in order to increase his merchandise. The former loans were of MZN 9,000 and MZN 15,500, all destined to the same activity.

In the future, he wishes to request more loans in order to expand his yard and to buy a vehicle as means to transport merchandise.


Translated from Portuguese by Giovanna Fernandes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy and selling of merchandise (beer, soft drinks, juice and others)

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Sabougnouma sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 42 ans et 3 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de MARKA COUNKO, sous préfecture de FANA, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parentés. Elles exercent le commerce d’articles divers il y’a un peu longtemps de cela. 
Ces femmes collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. 
Elles sont à leur sixième prêt solidaire et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires et d’articles divers tels que les habillements et les produits de premières nécessités. 
Les articles achetés en gros à Bamako et sur place, sont revendus sur place à MARKA COUNKO à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 25 000F CFA par mois. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of Sabougnouma Group (the "good cause") are married women who, on average, are 42 years old and have three children. They live with their husband and children in large traditional families in the village of Marka Counko, subprefecture of Fana, in the region of Kolikoro of the Republic of Mali. They know each other through neighborhood and family links.

These women have been merchants of various articles for quite some time. They have joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to ensure the long-term success of their businesses. This is their sixth solidarity loan. They have repaid all their previous loans on schedule.

They will use this new loan to buy a large quantity of food condiments and various articles such as clothes and basic household necessities. They will buy these products wholesale in Bamako and on location, and then retail them in Marka Counko to a clientele made up of women and men.

They expect to make an average monthly profit of 25,000 CFA francs each. They will reinvest part of their profit in their businesses and use part of it to contribute to the daily expenses of their families.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various articles

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more soft drinks to sell

loans.name: Nkodo V Evas Eyebasibwe Group

texts.en:
Evas E. is a twenty-six-year-old businesswoman. She lives with her spouse, who is the loan group representative. They are blessed with three children, two of whom go to school, and also care for two dependents, who are in school. 

Evas sells spare parts. She has been involved in this business for over six years. She is using the loan to purchase spare parts to sell. She is a hard-working business woman whose dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts to sell

loans.name: Chuop

texts.en:
Chuop Y., age 35, is a widow and the mother of two children. Chuop Y. was married, but divorced her husband many years ago. She now earns her income by working as a tailor in the factory. To help feed her family, one of her daughters works with her at the same place. 

Chuop Y. wants to generate extra income by selling rice, but she doesn’t have capital to start the business. Therefore, she would like a loan of $1200 to buy mature rice in bulk from farmers, which she will resell to earn more income.

loans.use: To buy mature rice in bulk from farmers to resell

loans.name: Nkodo 2 Nakalema Loyce Group

texts.en:
N. Loyce is thirty-five years old and her loan group representative. She is married and has eight children who are all in school. 

Loyce has been selling goats for three years. She is using her loan to purchase goats from remote villages and bring them to Ntungamo town to sell. Because she has less capital, she is topping-up to purchase at least ten goats. She is a very creative businesswoman whose dream is to improve her business and educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase goats to sell

loans.name: Benkola Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benkola sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 41 ans et 2 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le quartier de Fana coura, de la ville de Fana, sous préfecture de Fana Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de parentés. Elles exercent le commerce d’articles divers depuis maintenant  quelques années.  
Ces femmes collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives.  Elles sont à leur onzième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, des fruits et légumes et une grande quantité d’habillements et de chaussures. Les fruits et légumes sont achetés en gros avec les transporteurs venant de Lomé en partance pour Bamako et quant aux habillements, ils sont achetés à Bamako (capitale du Mali). 
Tous les produits sont  revendus sur place au marché de Fana à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 40 000F CFA par mois. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the Benkola group are married women with an average age of 41 and on average 2 children. They live with their husband and children in large traditional families and reside in the neighborhood of Fana Coura, in the town of Fana, sub-prefecture of Fana, Region of Koulikoro, Republic of Mali.

They know each other through their neighborhood and kinship. For the last few years they have been selling various items.

These women work in collaboration with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to continue their moneymaking activity. This is their eleventh group loan; all the previous loans have been fully reimbursed.

With this loan they wish to buy fruits and vegetables and a large quantity of clothing and socks. The fruits and vegetables are bought wholesale from the fret carriers coming from Lomé and leaving for Bamako. The clothing is bought in Bamako, the capital of Mali.

All the items are sold on the market place in Fana to customers made up of women and men.

They are planning for each one to make an average monthly profit of 40,000 CFA. The profits are in part reinvested in the activity and the other part goes to the family’s daily expenses.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various articles

loans.name: Ailina Julia

texts.pt:
Ailina Júlia Parkin nasceu na cidade de Maputo, Província de mesmo nome, tem 26 anos de idade, solteira e mãe de 2 filhos de 3 e 1 anos de idade. Continua estudando a 12ª classe. Vive na casa própria com seus filhos, e não sustenta mais ninguém.

Saiu da cidade de Maputo para Boane em casa dos pais e trabalha como caixa nas bombas de combustível da GALP na vila de Boane há Maios de 3 anos. Esta actividade aprendeu a 5 anos, num posto de abastecimento de combustível PETROMOC. Faz cerca de 14 horas de tempo de trabalho por dia e tem um salário mensal de 3.000.00mt que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum no banco comercial BCI.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de amigos que também são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu 2º empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar materiais de construção (cimento, pedra, areia e outros) para dar continuidade com a sua obra. O empréstimo anterior também foi no valor de 15.000.00mt para a mesma actividade.
 
 Futuramente gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para terminar a sua obra e ainda construir um murro de vedação.
texts.en:
Ailina Júlia Parkin was born in the city of Maputo, in the province of Maputo. She is 26 years old and is a single mother of her 2 children, ages 3 and 1. She continued her studies through the 12th grade. She lives in her own home with her children and does not support anyone else. She left Maputo for the city of Boane with her parents. She has worked pumping gas at a GALP gas station in Boane for the past three years. She learned this job five years ago while working at a PETROMOC gas station. She works about 14 hours a day and earns a monthly salary of 3.000.00mt that she uses to pay her househould expenses and saves a small amount in the commercial bank BCI. She has never had loans with other banks and she found out about Hluvuku through friends that are also Hluvuku clients. This is her second loan for 15.000.00mt that she will use to buy construction materials (cement, bricks, sand, and others) to continue working on her project. Her previous loan was for 15.000.00mt that she used for the same purpose. In the future she would like to apply for more loans in order to finish her project and to build a retaining wall.

Translated from Portuguese by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: construction materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase ingredients in bulk.

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Djekafo de l’association Garantie sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 35 ans et 4 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le quartier de Fana coura de la  ville de FANA, sous préfecture de FANA, Région de KOULIKORO, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à  travers des liens de voisinage et de parentés. Elles exercent le commerce d’articles divers depuis plusieurs années. 
Ces femmes collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pérenniser leurs activités lucratives. 
Elles sont à leur dixième prêt solidaire et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce prêt elles comptent acheter, des colis de différentes sortes d’articles divers,  des paquets   d’habillements et  des dizaines de paires chaussures. 
Les articles sont achetés en gros sur place avec les grossistes. 
Tous les produits sont  revendus sur place à la maison soit au marché à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 40 000F CFA par mois. Les bénéfices sont d’une part réinvestis dans l’activité et d’autre part dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille.
texts.en:
The members of the group Djekafo of the association Garantie are married women averaging 35 years of age and 4 children each.  Along with their husband and children, the women live in large traditional families and reside in the Fana Coura district of the city of FANA, sub-prefecture of FANA, Region of KOULIKORO, Republic of Mali.  They know one another through ties of community and kinship.  They have been doing commerce in a variety of goods for several years.  These women are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of ensuring that their lucrative businesses keep going.  The women are now on their tenth solidarity loan.  All the previous ones have been properly repaid.  With this loan, they intend to buy packages of different kind of goods, packets of clothing, and dozens of pairs of shoes.  The goods are purchased in bulk locally from wholesale merchants.  All the goods are sold locally either at the house or at the market, to customers composed of women and men.  The group members each envision realizing an average profit of 40,000 francs CFA per month.  The profits are in part reinvested into the business and put toward day-to-day family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase food to sell in her genge (food stall)

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia G. lives in the village of Hda Alejandria in Barangay La Granja, La Carlota City, Negros Occidental. She is 46 years old, married, and blessed with 3 children between 11 to 23 years old, with the oldest already in college. Her dream is for her children to finish their studies and help her to improve their lives. 

Many years ago, she worked as a bookkeeper in a sugar cane plantation, but she lost her job when the farm was divided among the long-time laborers through the government's agrarian reform program. Her employer offered to transfer her to their home office in the city, but she refused the offer because she wanted to stay close to her family.

The new development in her life prompted her to start her own business to help her husband support their family. In 2003, she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon to get access to capital so that she could open a general store. Because of her business background, she proved to be a good entrepreneur and her business soon flourished and expanded to include RTW (ready-to-wear) clothes and electronic loading (of pre-paid credits for text messaging) of mobile phones. She was also able to invest in a poultry business, starting with just 12 chicken. She now raises 41 chickens, which contributes a lot to her family's income. Her net profit per month averages PHP 6,400 (~ $139 USD). 

She used her previous loan of Php 7,000 as additional capital for her general store. That loan was fully repaid without delay. Now for her 16th loan, she is borrowing Php 19,500 to buy additional chicks, feed, and vitamins for her poultry business. She plans to use the income from her loan to pay for her children's education and other family expenses.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros  Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the  lives of thousands of women through Project  "Dungganon" (a Hiligaynon word that means "Honorable"). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is  empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to  achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a  life path that will ultimately make them "Dungganon" -  a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has  earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy chicks and feed for her poultry business

loans.name: Sitba

texts.en:
Sitba B. sells onions in the market. She is requesting a loan to buy other items like tomatoes, maize, and groundnut paste, to sell. Sitba is 25 years old and is married to a farmer. She has 5 children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children.

loans.name: Touch

texts.en: Touch V. is the director of a private school and earns a salary of $200 per month to manage his family’s living expenses. His wife is a teacher for a local public school (she appears in the picture). This couple has a young son who is not enrolled in school. Touch V. is experienced at raising animals, a skill he learned from his grandparents, who died of senility years ago. He now hopes to review his knowledge by requesting a Kiva loan of $1200 to build a medium-size stall where he will breed many animals. This will allow him to earn more income to ensure that his family attains a better standard of living.

loans.name: Glória Paulo

texts.pt:
Glória Paulo N. L. nasceu no Distrito de Marracuene, Província de Maputo, tem 51 anos de idade, viúva e mãe de 4 filhos que apenas se recorda da idade 1 que tem 15 anos ainda frequentando a escola. Vive na casa própria com seus filhos no Distrito de Boane na localidade de Mafuiane, e sustenta 2 netos que vivem com ela.

Saiu de Marracuene para Boane com 19 anos de idade, quando se casou com seu marido. Trabalha como agricultora há mais de 30 anos. É dona de 2 parcelas de 2 hectares cada e conta onde produz hortícolas e cereais com ajuda de uma empregada e seus filhos. Faz um horário das 7h as 16 horas todos os dias, consegue um rendimento de cerca de 12.000.00mt depois de 45 dias que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum através de Xitique (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa).

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de amigas que também são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu 4º empréstimo no valor de 13.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar insumos agrícolas (sementes, insecticidas, adubos e outros) para aumentar ainda mais as áreas de produção e oferecer a melhor qualidade de produtos.
Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 2.800.00mt, 11.000.00mt, 11.000.00mt e 15.000.00mt para a mesma actividade.
 
Futuramente gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para construir um aviário, para a criação de frangos de corte.
texts.en:
Glória Paulo N. L. was born in the Marracuene District, Maputo Province. She is 51 years old, a widow, and the mother of 4 children. One is 15 years old and still in school. She lives in her own house with her children in the Boane District in the town of Mafuiane, and supports two grandchildren that live with her. She left Marracuene for Boane at 19 years old, when she married her husband. She has worked as a farmer for more than 30 years. She owns 2 parcels of land that are 2 hectares each; she grows greens/vegetables and grains with the help of an assistant and her children. She works from 7am to 4pm every day, and brings in about 12,000 MZN in 45 days. She uses this for housing expenses and she even saves some through Xitique (a traditional system of revolving savings). She has never had loans through other banks. She became familiar with Hluvuku through some friends who are clients of this institution. She is her 4th loan. It has a value of 13,000 MZN, and she plans to use it to buy agricultural supplies (seeds, insecticides, fertilizers, etc.) in order to expand into more areas of production and offer products with better quality. Her previous loans were for 2,800, 11,000, 11,000, and 15,000 MZN, all for the same purpose. In the future, she would like to request more loans to build a coop, so she can raise chickens to butcher.

Translated from Portuguese by Erika Korowin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy agricultural supplies for the growing of greens/vegetables

loans.name: Von

texts.en: Von Y., 33, is a palm climber who has used his skill in tapping palm juice by hand for more than eight years. He also turns palm juice into palm sugar for sale, earning $3 per day to feed his family. Besides this, he and his wife raise a few pigs and cultivate rice for extra income. They have two young kids who are dependent on their income. Von Y. is taking out his first loan to buy more palm steps and palm tanks for his palm climbing business.

loans.use: To buy more palm steps and palm tanks for his climbing business

loans.name: Oliver

texts.en: K. Oliver is 28 years old; she is married and blessed with four children. Two of them are going to school. She has a retail shop and has been in business for five years so far. She will use this loan to purchase retail items such as drinks and essentials like salt, soap, sugar, match boxes, and so forth. She is adding capital into her business to expand her stock. She is an active hardworking business lady whose plan is to work very hard to purchase land and improve upon her business.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as drinks and essentials like salt, soap, sugar, match boxes, and so forth

loans.name: Maria Joaniss

texts.pt:
Maria joaniss M. nasceu no Distrito de Boane, Província de Maputo, tem 57 anos de idade, solteira e mãe de 3 filhos de 29, 30 e 31 anos de idade, cada um vivendo actualmente no seu lar. Fez somente 2ª classe, não continuou porque os pais obrigaram lhe trabalhar na machamba e pastagem de gado bovino. Vive numa casa alugada com um neto e não sustenta mais ninguém. 

Já esteve a viver na Província de Cabo delgado norte de Moçambique desde 1983 a 2003, quando o seu esposo esteve a trabalhar naquela parcela do pais. É comerciante e dona do seu negócio há mais de 7 anos. vende mais amendoim, óleo, feijão e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 800.00mt por dia que aplica nas despesas familiares e ainda poupa algum através de Xitique (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa).

Já teve empréstimos na cooperativa de crédito (CCP) mais tarde decidiu parar. Conheceu a Hluvuku através de amiga (Sra. Florinda Timane) que também é cliente desta instituição e este é o seu 2º empréstimo no valor de 10.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (Feijão, farinha, amendoim e outros) para aumentar e diversificar ainda mais a sua mercadoria. O empréstimo anterior foi de 5.000.00mt para a mesma actividade.

Futuramente gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para iniciar com a construção da sua casa, uma vez que actualmente vive numa casa de aluguer.
texts.en:
Maria Joaniss M. was born in the Boane District, Maputo Province. She is 57 years old, single, and the mother of 3 children who are 29, 30, and 31 years old. They each live in their own home. She only studied through 2nd grade and did not continue because her parents made her work on a small farm and in a cattle pasture. She lives in a rented house with a grandson and does not support anyone else besides him. She lived in the Cabo Delgado province in northern Mozambique from 1983 to 2003 when her husband worked in that part of the country. She is a merchant and has owned her own business for more than 7 years. She sells peanuts, oleo, beans, and brings in about 800 MZN per day, which she puts toward family expenses. She even saves some through Xitique (a traditional system of revolving savings). She has had four loans with the Credit Cooperative (CCP) but later decided to stop. She became familiar with Hluvuku through a friend (Mrs. Florinda Timane), who is a client of the institution. This is her 2nd loan, which has a value of 10,000 MZN. She would use this to buy products (beans, flour, peanuts, etc.) in order to expand and further diversify her merchandise. Her previous loan of 5,000 MZN was used for the same purpose. In the future, she would like to request a loan to build a house, since she actually lives in a rented one.

Translated from Portuguese by Erika Korowin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy and sell products (beans, flour, peanuts, etc.)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a dryer.

loans.name: Merei

texts.en: A. Merei is 39 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Khovd province in western Mongolia. She and her family live in a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent called a "ger". Her three children, two daughters and one son, all attend a local secondary school. Merei operates a vegetable trading business at a local market in her town. She started her business in 1995 and has built a stable operation over the years. She attributes her success to her hardworking nature and good personality. Merei hopes to continue her success and expand her business in the future. She is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug loan to purchase vegetables to sell in her business. About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables to sell

loans.name: Eufracia

texts.en:
Mrs. Eufracia C. is happily married and gifted with four children. She operates a business which is the buying and selling of junk items. Her average gross sales is about 2,000 pesos per day which can really help with their daily expenditures.

Eufracia sells her junk items daily. She is requesting a loan of 5,750 pesos so she can buy more junk items which she will then sell again. She is quite happy in her business and has it expand as people become more aware of recycling. 
  
Eufracia is already on her 8th loan and her previous loan was 5,500 pesos. She's very thankful that her business is growing fast with the help of her micro-finance loans from PMPC.


About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Leyla

texts.en:
Leyla P. is a 32-year-old woman who has dedicated her life to cattle breeding. That is why, seven years ago, she decided to move forward with raising livestock. She began with just one cow. Every morning, she goes out early so that her beloved cows may graze among the hills all day in hopes that they return happy and satisfied.

Leyla is motivated to continue in this arduous work by the thought of her future and her parent who is under her charge. In order to succeed in her business, she and her family look to nourish the animals and keep them happy, in hopes of ultimately selling them at a good price. 
However, with the support of this loan, Leyla would now like to purchase more species of livestock to increase her clientele. With your support, she will be able to accomplish her business goals, thus helping to improve her life conditions.

loans.use: To purchase three cattle and fodder

loans.name: Sherifat

texts.en: Sherifat is 40 years old and married with four children. She sells clothes and has been in this business all her life.  Therefore, she has the experience of ensuring that her customer's demands are met. She lives in Ibadan Oyo state Nigeria. She helps her husband support the family. Sherifat has a plan to expand her business. She is requesting a loan of N50,000 to increase her clothing business. She believes that having an assortment of women's outerwear that is of good quality will increase her sales. She say thank you to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Sahib

texts.en: Sahib Q. is a married man with three children. For several years has dedicated himself to cattle breeding. He has attended to this work with great effort in order to maintain his home. He has the duty of supporting his family and for this reason, he decided to come to AqroInvest Credit Union for help in buying young cattle. It is his dream to develop his business with more loans and in this way continue to maintain his humble home. Sahib promises to repay this loan in a timely manner and thanks all KIVA lenders for trusting and supporting him.

loans.use: To purchase three calves

Wani is 28 years old and is married to a soldier. She has four children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a bar and restaurant in the trading centre.
