loans.name: Alaba

texts.en: Alaba is excited to take a Kiva loan. She is 30 years old and married with two children.  She sells tailoring materials and has been in the business for the past 13 years. She is requesting a loan of N50,000. She will use this loan to buy tailoring materials in bulk to get a better price. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Santo Domingo Group

texts.en: The Santo Domingo Committee is in their first loan cycle. They were formed through the initiative and entrepreneurial spirit of 19 talented women. Their shared goal of bettering their lives drives them to work each day. All women already had independent and productive businesses when they took out the loan as a group. They use their loans to enhance their businesses, such as bakeries and pantries, buying ingredients for food, purchasing fruit and vegetables at bulk for resale, buying and re-selling cold beverages on hot days, buying second hand items such as clothes and shoes to re-sell. They hope to continue growing their businesses and be able to provide for their children. They share a goal of investing in their children’s education so they can have a brighter future.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Oluwaseyi

texts.en: Oluwaseyi is 35 years old and married with 3 children. He sells motor parts in a location which is very favorable for most of his customers. He lives in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. His wife is a nurse and they both contribute to supporting the family. With the loan of NGN 100,000, he plans to expand his business of selling motor parts. Most of the challenges he faces in his business are related to capital; he believes that with enough capital he will get a large quantity of good quality goods to help him increase his sales. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more spare parts to sell.

loans.name: Sagrado Corazon Group

texts.en:
The Sagrado Corazon committee is on its second loan. It is made up of twenty very hardworking women, many of whom are single mothers.

In this Group, the loans are used for the individual businesses of the members, which include, the recycling of paper, coal and plastics, buying ingredients for baked goods and pastries, such as the Paraguayan national “empanada”, fruits and vegetables, cosmetics such as lipsticks, creams, shampoos and deodorants, candy, fabric for tailoring clothing, bed sheets and towels, skirts and shorts, herbs and remedies, sausages and sweetmeats.

The women in this committee are all very experienced entrepreneurs and share the goals of overcoming poverty and succeeding in bettering their livelihoods.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise

loans.name: Martha Njeri

texts.en: Martha is 48 years old and married. She has a shop where she sells clothes to her customers in Ruiru. She has been in the business for about one year with a profit of about 40,000 KES per month. Martha wants to use the loan to add more stock of clothes for the festive season. She was introduced to KADET by her sister. This is her first loan from KADET and she hopes to improve her living standards and open another shop one day. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy more stock of clothes for the festive season

loans.name: Silas Mwakima

texts.en: Silas is a 29-year-old single man. He has a printing shop in Jericho, Nairobi. He feels his business is successful and wants to open a new outlet in the city center. He has been in the business for about two years with a profit of about 70,000 KES per month. Silas was introduced to KADET by a friend and has never borrowed from another micro-finance institution. He hopes to have many outlets that will enable him improve his standard of living. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.name: Benson Nyaoge

texts.en: Benson is 32 years old and married with two children. He sells new and secondhand clothing, as well as chickens and fresh eggs. He has been in these businesses for about eleven years and earns a profit of about 50,000 a month. Benson wants to use the loan to buy new and secondhand clothes and also additional chickens and eggs to sell to his customers. He was introduced to KADET by a friend and hopes to open a big boutique in order to improve his family's standard of living, especially for his children. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy new and secondhand clothes as well as chickens and eggs to sell

loans.name: Francisca Mwikali

texts.en: Francisca Mwikali is 42 years old and married with three children. She has a shop where she makes curtains to sell to customers as well as making custom orders. She has been in the business for about ten years and earns a profit of about 60,000 KES per month. Francisca wants to use the loan to buy more fabric and materials for making curtains. She has never borrowed from another micro-finance institute and was introduced to KADET by a friend. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy fabric and materials to make curtains for customers

loans.name: Bola

texts.en:
Bola sells crates of eggs at retail prices to her customers. She is 44 years old and is married with three children. Her husband is a farm manager.

Bola has been in this business for six years and sells for long hours to meet the basic needs and necessities of her family. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more crates of eggs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of eggs to sell

loans.name: Emily

texts.en: Emily is 34 years old and married with two children. She has been in the dressmaking business for about one year now and earns a profit of approximately 7,000 KES per month. She wants to use the loan to purchase dressmaking materials (fabric, buttons, etc). Emily was introduced to KADET by a friend and has never borrowed from any other micro-finance institution. She hopes to expand her business and also one day employ more people. This will enable her to meet the demand she receives from customers as well as to help give back to others in the community. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy dressmaking materials for her business

loans.name: Ann Wangechi

texts.en: Ann is 25 years old and married with two children. She has a beauty salon in Kikuyu town which is her primary business. She has been in the business for about one year and she makes a profit of approximately 16,000 KES. Ann was introduced to KADET by a friend who is also a client. She has never borrowed from another micro-finance institution but this will be her third loan from KADET. She has repaid the other loans on time. Ann wants to use this loan to buy a hairdryer for her primary business, as well as to buy clothes to sell to others. She hopes to improve her salon and also employ at least two more workers one day. She also wants to expand her secondary business, a small boutique. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy a hairdryer for her beauty salon and clothes to sell

loans.name: Reph Opiyo

texts.en:
Reph Opiyo is a 24-year-old single man who sells kerosene from his small shop in the Jerusalem estate in Nairobi.  He has been in this business for two years and earns a profit of about 75000 KES per month. With this loan, he wants to open a small pharmacy and add to his inventory of kerosene. 

Reph has never borrowed from another MFI and was introduced to KADET by a friend. He hopes to improve his living standards by one day owning a petrol station and pharmacy and he also hopes to create employment for other people.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To open a pharmacy and purchase kerosene to sell

loans.name: Laban

texts.en:
Laban is 29 years old and married to Lucy Wairimu, who is 26 years old. Together they have one daughter. Laban has run a beauty shop for 5 years. He now wants to set up a butchery in Mwiki, next to where his beauty shop is. 

Laban has never borrowed from another MFI and this will be his first loan with KADET. He wants to use the loan to set up a place where he can sell diffent types of meat. He hopes to open supermarkets in different areas of the country one day. His dream is to improve his standard of living for his family and he views opening a butchery as part of his plan.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: For setting up a butchery

loans.name: Olugbemiro

texts.en:
Olugbemiro sells textbooks at retail prices to his customers in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. He has been in this business for four years and he hopes to own a bookshop in the future.

Olugbemiro is 42 years old and married with a child. His wife is a civil servant. He is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more textbooks to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more textbooks to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional goods in bulk for her business

loans.name: Morike

texts.en:
Morike is a focused, hard-worker and puts in long hours trying to keep her businesses sustainable. She is 48 years old and is married with six children. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria.

Morike sells drinks and groceries like milk, soap, etc. Her husband sells motor parts and they both contribute to supporting the family.

Morike is requesting the loan of N50,000 to purchase more hot drinks and groceries. With this kind of business she hopes to increase her earnings in the long run and be able to better provide for her children's education. She say thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and groceries to sell

loans.name: Pola Mwagiria

texts.en: 52-year-old Pola Mwagiria is married to Katana Kabata. They have four children. Pola operates her business in Chocha-Malindi where she sells charcoal and also fish from which she gets a monthly profit of Ksh 4,000. She also does a bit of farming on the side. Pola was introduced to KADET by a friend who is an existing client. With this loan, Pola plans to purchase more charcoal to sell to her customers, as well as to use some of the funding to repair her business premises. With the profits she anticipates to earn as a result of this loan Pola hopes to buy a water tank and supply water to people around her and to build rental houses on her newly acquired plot of land. Pola describes herself as a hardworking woman. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy bags of charcoal and to repair her business premises

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah N. is 25 years old and has three school-aged children. She is married to John Mathege, and she and her husband are both in business. Hannah runs a general store. This is her first loan from KADET. She has never borrowed from any micro-finance institution before, but was introduced to KADET by a friend who is a KADET client. Hannah will use this loan to acquire more inventory to sell from her store, including bread, flour and soap. These purchases will allow her to meet the high demand during the Christmas season. Her dream and aspiration is to own a major wholesale shop.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy more inventory to her general store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more ingredients she can cook in her cafe.

loans.name: Oluyemi

texts.en: Oluyemi makes a living selling bags of cement in both wholesale and retail markets in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. She is 43 years old, married and has four children. Her husband is a lecturer and both he and his wife work very hard. Oluyemi has been in her line of work for three years, and has applied for a loan for 50,000 NGN to buy more bags of cement to sell. She extends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more bags of cement to sell

loans.name: Morrison

texts.en:
Morrison K. is 52 years old and has one child with his wife Joyce K.. He has been in the clothing business for the last four years. Morrison has just applied for a loan from KADET, the only micro-finance institution he has ever done business with. He learned about KADET through various marketing and promotion activities carried out by people in Naivasha town, where he lives.

Morrison will use this loan to increase his stock of items, such as pants and shirts, in order to meet high demand during the Christmas season. His future goal is to own his own boutique.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy more clothing to sell to customers during the holidays season

loans.name: Agali Awamu Nanono Marriam Group

texts.en: Marriam N. is both a loan group leader and a hardworking business woman. She is a widow with two children who has made a living selling clothes for the last 13 years. Marriam has applied for a loan to buy more clothing to sell to her customers. The loan will help her improve upon her business. She believes she can do this because she works very hard, is committed to raising her living standards and wishes someday to travel to Mecca for a pilgrimage.

loans.use: To buy more clothing to sell to her customers

loans.name: Margret

texts.en: Margret raises chickens to sell. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to make more profit during this season. She is 55 years old and married with four children. Her husband is a civil servant and he also supports the home. She has been in this business for a long time. She sells for long hours to meet the basic needs of the family. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more poultry birds to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more poultry birds to sell

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en: Isaac is 38 years old and married with a child.  He lives in Ibadan Oyo State, Nigeria. He sells bags of dried pepper and has been selling it for the past seven years.  With this business, he is able to support his family's basic needs and other necessities. With the loan of N50,000, he plans to expand his bags of dried pepper business, which is now booming. With this kind of business, he hopes to increase his earnings in the long run and be able to provide better for his children's education. He say thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of dried pepper to sell

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Eunice sells foodstuffs and groceries at retail prices to her customers. She is 40 years old and married with four children. Her husband sells bicycle spare parts in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. She has been in this business for a long time. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs and groceries to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and groceries to sell

loans.name: God's Grace Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth J. is the leader of a group of four borrowers called God’s Grace. She is 32 years old and a single mother with three children aged 3-13 years old. They are in Kindergarten through 5th grade. She also cares for two siblings. She is a 5th grade drop-out due to lack of financial support. Elizabeth and her children live around the Gbarnga central market but she works in the Gbarnga Dry rice market, Gbarnga city, the capital of Bong County, Liberia.

Her business is selling plastic materials .She buys plastic materials like plastic plates, cups, spoons, bowls, etc. wholesale and sells at retail in the Gbarnga Dry rice market. Elizabeth has been running this business for two years and hopes to move her business to a shop. Transporting goods is the difficulty Elizabeth faces. Elizabeth’s good relationship with customers makes them always patronize her business. She needs this loan to purchase more goods to improve business. Elizabeth dreams of giving her family the best support.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary sells crates of drinks. She is also a tailor and she makes lovely designs for her customers. She is 45 years old married with four children. Her husband is a pastor. She has been in business for five years. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to make a profit during this season. She is requesting a loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Jeska

texts.en: Jeska S. Myanya, 65, is a remarkable woman who is a role model for her extended family and her borrowing group.  Her husband died young as did three of her children. Jeska she is raising their six remaining children on her own. She quit her job as a cleaning woman for the city council and set out to start a small businesses with her family.  In conjunction with her family members, she has started a mandazie business (a sweet breakfast baked good) for distribution to stalls, a flavored ice business to sell to nearby schools, a fish business, as well as chipatis, cooked beans and sambeesas (a snack) to sell to food stalls and restaurants. She will use this loan to start a new enterprise.  She will purchase processed coal cheaply from a factory near Tanzania to sell locally. She would like her grandchildren to be educated. They manage their small businesses with her and while never missing school.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal cheaply from a factory to sell locally

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James O. is a single man, 23 years old, and he lives in Kabarnet town. James' loan is for Kshs 40,000 and this is the first loan he has ever taken from an MFI. James owns a tailoring shop, which he started three years ago. From his business, he makes a profit of Kshs 12,000 a month. With this loan of Kshs 40,000 James wants to expand his business by purchasing textiles worth Kshs 10,000, buttons worth Kshs 3000, and a new machine worth Kshs 15,000 and use the rest for transport and other needed materials for his business. 

James was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend who was already a KADET client. James' customers are residents of Kabarnet town and the surrounding area. James hopes this loan helps his business reach the point where he can employ others as tailors. James' dream is to expand his business and even open another business in a nearby town. He also hopes to buy a plot of land where he will build himself a house, marry and have a happy family.

James describes himself as a hardworking and focused man.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy materials for making clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional products for her genge business.

loans.name: Karegyeya Kyakusimire Resty Group

texts.en: K. Resty is the group representative. She has four children. Three of the children are going to school. She also looks after one dependent. She has been a farmer on her own for over 20 years. She is using the loan on her plantations. She is managing to pay school fees for her children. She is an ambitious businesswoman whose dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, seeds, pay wages, and so forth

loans.name: Abiodun

texts.en:
Abiodun sells motor spare parts at retail prices to his customers. He is 46 years old and is married with four children. His wife sells foodstuffs to also support the home.

Abiodun has been in his business for a long time. He sells for long hours to enable him make more profits to support his home. He is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more motor spare parts to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more motor spare parts to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients for her business.

loans.name: Domitila Mumbua

texts.en: Domitila is a 24-year-old single parent with one daughter. She was introduced to KADET by an existing customer that operates her business nearby. Domitila has been operating a charcoal business for the last three years, from which she earns a monthly profit of Ksh 6,000. She will use 20% of her loan to repair her business premises and 50% to buy additional sacks of charcoal to sell to customers. With the remaining 30% she hopes to open another business selling vegetables. Domitila describes herself as a hardworking lady who is focused and wants to excel in business. She dreams of being a big business owner in Malindi town. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To repair her business premises, to buy more sacks of charcoal, and to open a grocery stand to sell vegetables

loans.name: Aminat

texts.en: Aminat has a salon where she makes lovely hairstyles for her customers. She also sells hair extensions and cream at retail prices to her customers in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. She is 35 years old and married with four children. She has been in this business for four years. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more hair extensions and cream to sell. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to make more profit. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and cream to sell

loans.name: Karegyeya Ainomugisha Fiona Group

texts.en: A. Fiona is the chairperson of her group. She is using the loan to purchase pub items such as crates of beers, sodas, and so forth to sell. She has been in her business for over two years. At least now she buys more than five crates of sodas, beers, boxes of water, wines, and so forth. She is stocking more and more for better profits. She is an active and hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase pub items to sell

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty is a 34-year-old married woman with three children between 4 and 13 years old. All her children go to school. She rents a two-room house where she is staying with five people. She takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water and gets three meals a day.  She incurs transport costs to and from buying Bitengi (African attire) from Arua, one of the many districts of northern Uganda and uses public transport to and from shopping. She works in a semi-urban area, which is on the outskirts of Kampala. Betty works six days a week. She receives an average of four customers a day and sells to all categories of people. She moves door-to-door selling African attire. Her major business challenges are highway thieves and the rainy season, which hinders her movements.  Betty has been in this business for four years and with MCDT for seven years, servicing her 14th loan. She wants to use this loan to buy more African attire. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and to own a permanent business premise.

loans.use: To buy more African attire to sell

loans.name: Kemi

texts.en:
Kemi sells sarongs of various colors and sizes at retail prices to her customers in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is 43 years old, married with 3 children. Her husband is an engineer and he also supports the household.

Kemi has been in this business for 5 years. She is requesting the loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Twekembe Amina Nabukenya Group

texts.en: Amina N. is the group president; she is a promissing business lady of thirty-one years old. She lives with her spouse and they are blessed with four children of whom two are going to school. She is using the loan to purchase restaurant items such as saucepans, plates, and so forth, plus renovating her restaurant. She is sensing a big change in her restaurant business. Her future plan is to prosper and change or improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase restaurant items such as saucepans, plates, etc. plus renovating the restaurant

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase cow so that she can butcher  and sell its meat retail

loans.name: Caren

texts.en:
Caren C. is a 30-year-old mother of 5. Caren is married to Francis Suter who is 45 years old.

Caren operates a cosmetics shop and salon, from which she generates profits of about Kshs 10,000 a month. She started this business five years ago. Caren's loan from KADET is worth Kshs 80,000. It's her second loan, and she repaid the first well. With this loan, Caren plans to purchase stock for her business since during the December festive season she has an increase in clients. Some of the items include cosmetics, hair treatment chemicals, synthetic hair and extra dryers.

KADET Ltd is Caren’s first and only financier (MFI); she was introduced to KADET by a community leader who is a KADET client.

Caren does her business in Kabarnet town; her clients are residents of Kabarnet town. If her business flourishes Caren plans to expand her business from retail to wholesale.

Caren dreams of opening a cosmetic wholesale shop and she describes herself as hard-working and determined to attain her goals.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: to buy cosmetics and a hair-drying machine

loans.name: Philip

texts.en:
Philip G. is 27 years old and married to Veronica Wanjiru. He has been in the general merchandise retail business for the last two years.

This is Philip’s second loan from KADET. He used the first loan to rent his current business premises since before that he used to do hawking door to door. He has never borrowed from any micro-finance institution before. He was introduced to KADET by a friend who is also a KADET client.

Philip will use this loan to further expand his current business premises (set up more shelves, improve the lighting, and restock his merchandise) so as to meet the high demand during the Christmas season. His future dream and aspiration is to own a supermarket and improve his quality of life.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: expand his business premises by setting up shelves, etc.

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William C. is 38 years old and married to Francisca Kipkorir. They are blessed with three children: Naomi Jelagat (five years old, in the top class), Timothy Kiprotich (two years old), and baby Dennis Kiptoo (five months old).
William runs a mini wholesale shop in Kabarnet town. He started this business three years ago, and now earns a monthly profit of 12,000 KES. This loan is William’s second loan from Kiva partner, KADET, and with it he plans to restock his wholesale shop in anticipation of the busy festive season of December.
The items William plans to buy are: wheat flour for 16,000 KES, rice for 15,000 KES, sugar for 8,000 KES, bar soap for 2,000 KES, sweets for 1,000 KES, cooking fat for 5,000 KES, washing powder (Omo and Sunshine) for 4,000 KES, toilet soap for 1,500 KES, washing detergents (Jik and Softa) for 2,500 KES, and cutlery for 20,000 KES. He will use the remaining money for transport.
William’s customers are residents of Kabarnet town. William believes that this loan will boost his business, and he plans to expand the business into a supermarket one day. William's dreams are to educate his children to the extent they wish, and to buy a plot of land within the town in order to build a structure for his business. (He currently rents the premises he uses at the moment.)
William describes himself as hardworking, optimistic and resourceful, and this is evident by his progress as a businessman. He started as a humble hawker of items, grew to become a retailer, and currently operates as a wholesaler.

About KADET
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To restock his wholesale business

loans.name: Prisca

texts.en:
Prisca K. is 36 years old and married to James Kibet who is 40 years old. Prisca has been blessed with three children: Hesbon Kiprotich (13 years, form 2), Faith Jepkemoi (10 years, class 8), and Jane Kimosop (7 years, class 4).
Prisca owns a mini hardware store, which she started four years ago. The store is in Kabarnet town and most of her customers are Kabarnet residents or from nearby villages. She earns a profit of 10,000 KES a month and an additional income of 3,000 KES from other sources.
This loan is Prisca's second loan from Kiva partner KADET – her first loan was for 35,000 KES and she repaid it well. Prisca plans to use this loan to expand her business by purchasing more hardware stock, such as jembes, sprayers, hammers, spades, and even a power saw. If this loan improves her business, Prisca plans to expand her business from retail to wholesale and educate her children to the highest level of education. Prisca describes herself as a hardworking and dedicated businesswoman.

About KADET
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy new stock for her hardware business

loans.name: Idowu

texts.en:
Idowu is 35 years old, and married with two children. Her husband sells electronics and also supports the home.
Idowu sells sarongs of various colors and sizes at retail prices to her customers in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. She has been in this business for a long time. She loves her work because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. Idowu is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Twekembe Nagawa Margaret Group

texts.en:
N. Margaret is a 30-year-old married woman who is blessed with two school-aged children, one of whom is in grade six and the other in grade two.
For the last eight years, Margaret has run a small business selling foodstuffs. This business enables her to pay her children's school fees. As she has only a small amount of capital and has to pay transport costs, she is requesting a loan to purchase bananas from villages to supply them in town markets.
Margaret is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to purchase a plot of land and construct a house so that she can earn a living by renting it out.

loans.use: To purchase bananas from villages to supply them in town markets

loans.name: Nabih

texts.en: Nabih is a 22-year-old single man who lives with his parents. In 2008, he decided to open his own curtain shop and thus began his new career. Today, Nabih is requesting to borrow $1,200 USD to buy a Rapid car to facilitate his business movements and be able to satisfy quickly his customers' demands.

loans.use: To buy a Rapid car

loans.name: Funso

texts.en:
Funso is 43 years old and is married with three children. His wife works for the government.

Funso has a poultry farm where he rears chickens to sell. He has been in this business for 5 years. He is a focused, hard-worker and loves this business because of the profits that it yields.

Funso is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more chicks to rear and sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more chicks to rear and sell

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein is a constructor working in this field since 1980. Over the years, thanks to his business income, he has been able to meet his 4 children's needs. Today, Hussein is asking for a loan of US$ 1,000 to buy wood and tools needed for his business.

loans.use: buy wood and tools

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein is a 33-year-old married man and father of 2 children who are unemployed. He has owned a farming supplies and an accesories shop since 2004 to make a good income for his family. Today, Hussein is requesting to borrow US$ 1,000 to purchase additional equipment and tools to develop his business productivity

loans.use: purchase additional equipment and tools

loans.name: Sarah Nabukeera  ‘S Group

texts.en:
Sarah is 49 years old and a single mother of four children aged between 10 and 20 years. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a three-roomed house where she is staying with four people. Sarah takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day. She incurs transport costs to and from buying merchandise from Kikuubo one of the busiest places in Kampala.

Sarah has a retail shop in Kyebando Nsooba selling all types of merchandise like sugar, salt, cooking oil, soap, Blue Band margarine, jerrycans (empty) and thread. She doesn’t pay rent as she works from her home. She works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 40 customers a day and sells to all categories of people, both retail and wholesale. Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees for her children.

Sarah's major business challenges are defaulters and the rainy season which hinders her from reaching her customers. She has been in this business for twenty years and with MCDT for eight years, servicing her seventeenth loan, working with the same group mates. Sarah joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise like sacks of sugar, cartons of salt, and boxes of soap. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and starting selling only wholesale.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise like sugar, salt, and boxes of soap

loans.name: Wartohi

texts.en: Wartohi is a 42-year-old woman with 2 children. She has owned a snack shop since 2008 and has a previous 16 years of experience in this market. Today, Wartohi is asking for a loan of US$ 1,200 to enlarge her shop and add new decor in order to attract new customers and make a good income.

loans.use: enlarge her shop and add new decor

loans.name: Adebukola

texts.en: Adebukola sells crates of drinks at wholesale and retail prices to make a living. She is a focused, hard worker. She is 49 years old, a widow with 2 children. She takes care of the welfare of her children alone. She has been in this business for 3 years. She is requesting the loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more drinks to sell. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to meet the demand of her customers. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Mohsen

texts.en: Mohsen is a 20-year-old single man living with his family. He has five years of experience in air-conditioning. He has owned a shop since 2004. Today he is requesting to borrow $1,000 to buy a car to facilitate his business movements and satisfy the needs of customer, and increase his income.

loans.use: Buy a car for air-conditioning business

loans.name: Ryangusha Nalongo Teddy Group

texts.en: N. Teddy is the president of this group, a hard-working business woman of forty-five years old. She is a widow with five children of whom two are going to school. She has been rearing livestock so far for twenty years. She is using the loan to purchase more animals to add to her livestock. She wants to enlarge and boost her business. She is also looking forward to fencing her farm for security purposes.

loans.use: To purchase more animals to add to her livestock

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is 48 years old and married with thirteen children, aged between 10 and 20 years. All her children go to school. She resides in and owns a four-roomed house where she is staying with eight people. Betty takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water and gets three meals a day. She incurs transport costs to and from buying fruit from Nakawa market.

Betty has a stall selling all sorts of fruit and vegetables like mangoes, paw paws, pineapples, eggplant, and cabbages. She pays dues of 1000/= per day. She works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 40 customers a day and sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale. Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees for her children and monthly market dues for her business.

Her major business challenges are defaulters and the rainy season which hinders her from reaching her customers. She has been in this business for eighteen years and with MCDT for eight years, servicing her seventeenth loan, working with the same group-mates. Betty joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more baskets of mangoes, pineapples, eggplant, and cabbages. She wants to see her business grow bigger and to start buying directly from farmers.

loans.use: To buy more baskets of fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Hasan

texts.en: Hasan is a 39-year-old married man with three children. Hasan has 14 years of previous experience in the construction field. Today, Hasan is requesting to borrow US$ 1,000 to buy new tools to better satisfy the needs of his clients and to increase his income to help improve his living situation.

loans.use: buy new tools

loans.name: Alfa Y Omega 1,2 & 3 Group

texts.en:
Ana is the coordinator of her group Alfa y Omega (Alpha and Omega), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti). Her group is located in the areas surrounding Santiago, the DR's second largest city, which is located in the Cibao valley and is famous for agricultural production. In this area, however, running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband and 4 children.

Ana is excited to be taking her second loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business, selling a variety of items that she has identified a market for, including inexpensive jewelry, shoes, and perfumes. She will use the profits to invest in her family and improving her home. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Shoes, perfumes, and jewelry to sell in her variety store

loans.name: Ryangusha Kamusime Anna Group

texts.en: K. Anna is thirty years old. She is married with three children, all going to school, and she looks after two dependents who are also schooling. She runs a pub and she has been doing this for two years. She is using the loan to purchase pub items for instance crates of drinks such as sodas, beer, water, and so forth for sale. She is a hard-working businesswoman who is now managing to pay the school fees of her children. Her future plan is to educate her children, to purchase a plot of land, and as well to prosper in life.

loans.use: purchasing pub items, for instance crates of drinks and so forth

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en: Ahmad is a 23-year-old single man living with his parents. Ahmad is a hard-working man and has three years' experience as a decorations specialist. Today he is requesting to borrow US$ 1,200 to buy appliances for his work to earn more income to satisfy the needs of his family.

loans.use: to buy appliances

loans.name: Fatmeh

texts.en: Fatmeh is a 21-year-old single woman living with her family, of whom 4 are employed. She has been working as hairdresser for five years to earn income to help satisfy the needs of the family, in collaboration with her brother. Today, Fatmeh is requesting to borrow US$ 1,000 to buy more merchandise so she can increase her sales and therefore her income.

loans.use: buy more merchandise

loans.name: Aminat

texts.en: Aminat is 45 years old, married with 4 children. Her youngest child is 5 years old. Her husband sells clothes to support the household. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. She sells kerosene and eggs at retail prices to her customers. With these combined businesses, she hopes to meet the basic needs of her family members. She is requesting the loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more kerosene and eggs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene and eggs to sell

loans.name: Muyumbu Kyasimire Byabashisha Group

texts.en: K. Byabashisha is a creative businesswoman, thirty-seven years old. She is married and blessed with five children schooling and taking care of three dependents, also schooling. She operates a retail shop which she has been running for over ten years. She is using the loan to purchase retail items such as soap, sugar, sweets, bread, cooking oil, beans, and so forth for sale. The loan is helping her to increase the profit from her business. She is a hard-working businesswoman as well as group representative, and her dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as soap, sugar, sweets, bread, cooking oil, beans, and so forth for sale

loans.name: Moufida

texts.en: Moufida is a 30-year-old single woman. She has owned a beauty salon since 1990. She is living with her parents and her brother. Moufida is now requesting to borrow US$ 1,200 to improve her shop and buy new products to satisfy her customers.

loans.use: improve her shop

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth B. is 45 years old and married with four children. Her eldest child is 16 years old. Elizabeth lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. She bakes and sells cakes. She also sells baking ingredients, such as bags of flour and baking powder, at retail prices to her customers. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to make more profits during this season. 

Elizabeth is requesting a loan in the amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more baking ingredients to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baking materials for resale

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en: Mahmoud is 32 years old and married with one child. He has been working in construction for nine years. Today, Mahmoud is asking to borrow $1,000 to buy specialized machinery that will help to satisfy his customers' needs and increase his income.

loans.use: To buy specialized machinery

loans.name: Olajumoke

texts.en: Olajumoke, 40, is a widow with three children. Her eldest child is 11 years old and the youngest child is six years old. Olajumoke lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. She sells gift items at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to own a shop in the future. She is requesting a loan in the amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more gift items to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more gift items to sell

loans.name: Wissam

texts.en: Wissam is 28 years old and married with one child. Wissam has owned a phone shop where he buys new and used phones. In 2007, he also started repairing phones. Today, Wissam is requesting to borrow $1,000 to buy more phones and phone tools, so he can increase his sales and therefore his income.

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Jesus Es Mi Piloto 3 & 4 Group

texts.en:
Nuris is the coordinator of her group, Jesus es mi Piloto (Jesus is my Pilot), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients. Her group is located in the slums surrounding Santiago, an agricultural center famous for tobacco and beef production where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure as single mother with her child.

Nuris is excited to be taking her first loan with Esperanza. She plans to use this loan to invest in a business selling clothing in her community. Her business plan calls for taking orders from her neighbors and then travelling to the capital city to purchase the items in bulk at a low price and then selling the items at a profit. She will use the profits to improve her quality of life and invest in her family. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Purchasing clothing for resale

loans.name: Muyumbu Kagara Provia Group

texts.en: K. Provia, who represents her group, is 48 years old and married with 14 children, all of whom attend school. She also has two other dependents who are in school. K. Provia is a farmer and she has been a farmer for over 28 years. She is using the loan to purchase fertilizer, seeds, and so forth, for planting. She is hardworking and active. Her dream is to educate her children and improve upon her farming.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farming supplies

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Eunice is 40 years old and married with a child. Her only child is ten years old. Eunice is a friendly and hardworking woman. She sells building materials at retail prices to her customers. She sells for long hours to enable her to meet the basic needs of her family. She is requesting a loan in the amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more building materials to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more building materials to sell

loans.name: Kagborkua Group

texts.en:
Gorpu F. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Kagborkua. She is 49 years old and married with five children aged 10-32 years old. Her children's education levels 6th-12th grade. She also cares for three relatives. She is illiterate due to lack of financial support.

Gorpu and her family live around the Gbarnga central market but works in the Gbarnga general market in Gbarnga city, the capital of Bong County, Liberia. Her business is the sale of general goods. She buys general goods wholesale and sells at retail in the Gbarnga dry rice market.

Gorpu has been running this business for four years, and hopes to expand the business to a shop. The high price of goods is the only difficulty Gorpu faces. She talks to customers in a good manner in order to encourage them to always coming to patronize her business. 

She needs this loan to purchase more goods to improve her business. Gorpu dreams of building a house for her family in the near future.

loans.use: To improve her business by purchasing more goods for resale

loans.name: Miguel Angel

texts.es:
El Jóven Miguel Ángel de 25 años de edad vive con sus padres  en Calle Ica - Subtanjalla.
Es soltero, se dedica a la venta de especerías, condimentos y otros desde hace 3 años.
En su trabajo es bien dedicado, emprendedor y dá muy buena atención a sus clientes por lo que son fieles a él.
Solicita un financiamiento para poder invertir más en su negocio y para ver la posibilidad de estudiar una carrera técnica ya que trabaja desde las 6:00 a.m. hasta las 2:00 p.m. y en la tarde desea estudiar. Tiene muchas ganas de superación y realización personal y no lo ha podido lograr por falta de recursos económicos.
Goza de buenas referencias de parte de sus vecinos y de sus compañeros de trabajo.
texts.en:
The young man Miguel Ángel is 25 years-old, single, and lives with his parents on Ica Street, Subtanjalla. He has been working selling spices, condiments, and other products for three years. He is dedicated to his work, enterprising, and provides very good service to his customers, making them very loyal to his business. He is asking for a loan to invest more in his business, and to create the possibility of studying a technical career, as now he works from 6:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. and would like to study in the afternoon. Miguel Ángel strongly desires to overcome his obstacles and realize his personal goals, but has not yet been able to due to his lack of economic resources. He has good personal references from his neighbors and his coworkers.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Credo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expand his business with the sale of salads and vegetable stews.

loans.name: God Comes First Group

texts.en:
Felecia F. is a leader of a group of four borrowers called God Comes First. She is a youth without a child, but fending for herself through business. Her education level is eighth grade. She lives in the Frog Island Community in Gbarnga City, the capital of Bong County, Liberia.

Her business is the sale of general goods. She buys general goods wholesale and sells at retail to residents of Frog Island Community. Felecia has been running this business for two years, and is hoping to expand her business into a shop. Bad road conditions is a difficulty Felecia faces when transporting goods from wholesale to her business site. She talks to customers in a good manner in order to encourage them to always come to patronize her business. 

She needs this loan to purchase new kinds of goods to improve her business. Felecia dreams of building a house for her family in the near future.

loans.use: To purchase new kinds of goods to improve her business

loans.name: Katia Giovanna

texts.es:
La Sra. Katia Giovanna B. M. de 33 años de edad vive con su madre y su abuela junto con sus 3 hijos en Garganto – Los Aquijes – Ica.
Ella es madre soltera, profesora en un colegio de la zona donde vive y tiene un negocio de golosinas, gaseosas y otros. 
Es trabajadora tiene buenas referencias de parte de los vecinos. Trabaja en el colegio desde las 8:00 am hasta la 1:30 pm y mientras su madre la apoya en su negocio
Solicita el préstamo para incrementar el negocio que le da una buena rentabilidad y al mismo tiempo para inertir en la compra de juguetes y otros por campaña navideña.
texts.en:
Ms. Katia Giovanna B. M. is 33 years old and lives her her mother and grandmother and her 3 children in Garganto – Los Aquijes – Ica. She is a single mother, a school teacher in the area where she lives and she has a business selling candy, soft drinks and other treats. She is hard-working and has good references from her neighbors. She works at the school from 8:00 am to 1:30pm while her mother looks after her business. She is requesting the loan to expand her business to have a good profitability and at the same time in order to invest in buying toys and other things for the Christmas season.

Translated from Spanish by Lauren Jackson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: increase her business for the Christmas season

loans.name: Living Rock Group

texts.en:
Hellen K. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Living Rock. She is married with two children between the ages of 7 and 24 years old. Her children's education levels are 5th grade through university student. She also cares for seven siblings. She is a high school graduate but could not continue to university due to lack of financial support.

Hellen and her family live around the Ganta Parking Community of Gbarnga City, the capital of Bong County, Liberia. Her business is the sale of general goods. She buys general goods wholesale and sells at retail to residents of her community in Gbarnga. Hellen has been running this business for four years, and is hoping to improve her business by establishing a new enterprise in the near future.

The cost of transportation is a difficulty Hellen faces when purchasing goods from the wholesaler, because the higher the price of goods, the lower the profit. She talks to customers in a good manner and always tries to establish a relationship with customers in order to encourage them to always come to patronize her business. 

She needs this loan to purchase new goods to improve her business. Hellen dreams of giving her family the best help to give them a better life.

loans.use: To purchase new goods to improve the business

loans.name: Renecer De Ayar Maca Group

texts.es:
Nuestros socios, pertenecen al banco comunal “RENECER DE AYAR MACA”, viven en la comunidad Ayar Maca desde su nacimiento, ellos están situados a 20 minutos en auto de la localidad de Chincheros y ubicados a 1 hora de la ciudad del Cusco. 

Nuestros socios alternan sus diversas actividades del hogar, con la agricultura, ganadería, artesanía y el comercio minorista. 
En el comercio de la agricultura los socios venden papas, choclos y verduras. Ellos crían animales menores tales como las aves de corral y cuyes. Ellos se dedican a la venta de artesanías a los turistas que están de pasada por la comunidad. Ya son varios años que trabajan y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo, nuestros socios son personas trabajadoras y emprendedoras que quiere casar a adelante a sus hijos. Los socios requieren el préstamo para comprar animales, semillas y productos para la cosecha y la siembra así poder aumentar el capital del negocio y así tener mayores ingresos y darles a sus hijos una mejor calidad de vida.

Los socios valoran y agradecen el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y así mismo se comprometen a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The members of the Communal Bank “Renecer de Ayar Maca” have lived in the community of Ayar Maca since birth. The community is located 20 minutes away by car from the town of Chinceros and one hour away from the city of Cusco.

The members divide their time among their household activities, farming, raising animals, making crafts, and managing their small businesses. The agricultural products they sell include potatoes, corn, and vegetables. They raise small livestock such as poultry and guinea pigs. In addition, they sell handicrafts to tourists that pass through the community. They have been working for several years and have done very well as a result of the effort they invest into these endeavors. The members are hardworking, enterprising people who want to succeed for the sake of their children. They are requesting a loan to buy animals, seeds, and products for the harvesting and planting seasons. This will increase their business capital, help them generate more income, and provide their children with a better quality of life.

The members value and appreciate this opportunity and commit to making their payments on time.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase animals, seeds, and various supplies for the harvesting and planting seasons

loans.name: Survivor Group

texts.en:
Annie D. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Survivor. She is 26 years old and a single mother with a 4-year-old child in kindergarten .She also cares for a nephew. Annie is a fifth grade drop-out due to lack of financial support. Annie and her child live in the Frog Island Community of Gbarnga, the capital city of Bong County, Liberia.

Her business is the sale of palm oil. She buys palm oil wholesale and sells at retail to residents of her community in Gbarnga. Annie has been running this business for two years, and is hoping to improve her business by building a storage room for goods in the near future.

The rainy season is a difficulty for Annie, because when it rains, farmers hardly come out to cut palms to produce the oil that she buys; it causes an oil shortage in the market. 

Annie talks to customers in a good manner and sells her oil for an affordable price in order to encourage them to always come to patronize her business. She needs this loan to purchase new oil to serve customers. Annie dreams of building a house for her and her child.

loans.use: To purchase new oil to serve customers

loans.name: Juan Pablo

texts.es: Juan Pablo de 23 años de edad, es soltero, no tiene hijos, labora para el MINED de Santo Tomas desde hace casi 5 años como docente, su compañera de vida labora como empleada domestica y siempre lo apoya con los gastos familiares, esta solicitando su 2do credito y espera seguir siendo beneficiado con el Fondo Kiva  para comprar zinc, las puertas y las ventanas de su casita, la cual logro levantar con el credito anterior, pero aun le falta ponerle el techo y darle seguridad a su vivienda.  El mayor sueño de juan Pablo es poder terminar su casita para que cuando vengan los hijos tengan un hogar con las condiciones basicas en el cual puedan desarrollarse, ademas desea terminar la universidad para asi poder tener mejores oportunidades de trabajo.  Expresa que cuando cancele este credito solicitara otro para seguir acondicionando su casa.
texts.en:
Juan Pablo is 23 years old and single with no children. He has worked for the Santo Tomas MINED for almost 5 years as a teacher. His life partner works as a maid and always helps him with the household expenses. He is requesting his second loan and hopes to continue to be a beneficiary with the Kiva fund to buy zinc, doors and windows for his small house. With the previous loan he managed to build his house, but he needs to put on a roof and give it security. Juan Pablo's biggest dream is to finish his house so that when he has children, they have a home with the basic conditions in which to develop. Moreover, he wants to finish college so that he can have better job opportunities. He has expressed that when pays this loan, he will ask for another to continue preparing his home.

Translated from Spanish by Elycia Mulholland, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy zinc, doors, and windows for his home

loans.name: Ginna Denisse

texts.es: Ginna Denisse de 25 años es soltera, no tiene hijos, es Licenciada en Contabilidad, trabaja en BANCENTRO Juigalpa desde hace 4 años como cajera, habita junto a su mamá, quien le dio un pequeño espacio para construir su casita la cual ha ido acondicionando poco a poco poniendole ceramica a la sala y construyendo 2 cuartos, sin embargo les falta construir un pequeño garaje por lo que esta solicitando su 2do credito, pues tiene planes de matrimonio y su futuro esposo tiene un vehiculo y necesitan dejarlo en un lugar seguro, el novio trabaja como agente vendedor de medicamentos en los municipios aledaños y le apoya en esta gestion, ya que juntos desean que su hogar tenga las condiciones necesarias para cuando lleguen los hijos.  A pesar que ambos son jovenes son muy responsables con sus compromisos, Ginna es muy querida por sus compañeros de trabajo y tiene como meta seguir estudiando para lograr obtener mejores oportunidades de trabajo que le permitan seguir mejorando su casa.
texts.en:
Ginna Denisse is 25 years old and does not have any children. She has a degree in accounting and has worked as a cashier at Bancentro Juigalpa for four years. She lives with her mother, who gave her a small space to build her own house. Little by little, she has been setting it up, putting ceramic in the living room and constructing two bedrooms. However, they still need to build a small garage, for which she is requesting her second loan. She has plans to get married, and her future husband has a vehicle, which needs to be kept in a safe place. Her fiancee works as a medical salesman in the adjacent municipalities and supports her in this process, since together they desire to have a home that is adequate for when they have children. Despite both of them being young, they are very responsible with their commitments. Ginna is loved by her coworkers and has a goal to continue studying in order to obtain better job opportunities that will allow her to keep improving her house.

Translated from Spanish by Mark Broscoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction of a garage

loans.name: Sonia Alberta

texts.en:
Sonia is a single mother who opened a bakery 16 years ago as a way to support her two children. Both of her kids are now grown and studying in the university. Based out of her home, Sonia began her bakery with just a few items, but with time and the financial support of Fundación León 2000, it has become an established business. With this loan, she will purchase more ingredients to make her desserts. 

Sonia’s goal is to provide for her children’s education and to be able to ensure that her family doesn’t go without a meal. She dreams that one day, her children will be able to have a better way of life. Sonia knows that she will continue with her business even though the economic crisis has made life difficult in Nicaragua and around the world. Sonia is grateful for those who support her in her business.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for making desserts

loans.name: Ivania Del Carmen

texts.es: La señora Ivania posee un negocio que es una pulpería ubicada en su casa de habitación, ella comenzó su negocio vendiendo tortillas de manera ambulante, gracias a su esfuerzo, logro establecer el negocio que actualmente posee el cual es una pulpería, es madre de tres hijas las cuales están a su cargo, todas ellas asisten al colegio gracias al apoyo incondicional de la mama , la señora está solicitando un nuevo financiamiento para invertirlo en su negocio ya que sus clientes  están demandando diversidad de productos. A pesar de las circunstancias es una persona que quiere salir adelante con su negocio que es el único medio de ingresos que tiene.
texts.en:
Ivania has a business, a mini market, which is located in her house. She started her business selling tortillas as a street vendor. Thanks to her effort, she was able to establish the business she currently has, a mini market. She is raising her three daughters. They go to school thanks to the unconditional support of their mother. She is asking for a new loan to invest in her business. Her customers are requesting a variety of products. In spite of her circumstances, she is a person who wants to get ahead with her business. This is the only income that she has.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Zoila

texts.es:
La socia ZOILA  pertenece al banco comunal “VIRGEN PURIFICADA - ANGOSTURA” y es la presidenta.    

La socia tiene 49 años de edad, es divorciada. La socia vive en la distrito de San Jerónimo en la comunidad de Angostura que se encuentra ubicada al sur de la ciudad del Cusco. Nuestra socia tiene un stand en el Mercado Vino Canchón de San Jerónimo  donde vende comida (Desayuno, almuerzo y Cena) y también se dedica a la crianza de cuyes y gallinas. Ya son varios años que trabaja en el negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo, nuestra socia es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que quiere sacar adelante a su familia. La socia requiere el préstamo para comprar más insumos para preparar mas platos de comida y alimento para los animales que cría y después venderlos a un buen precio. De esta manera así poder aumentar el capital del negocio y para tener mejores ingresos y darle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida. 

La socia se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Zoila belongs to the Virgen Purificada-Angostura Communal Bank, and she is the president. She is 49 and divorced. She lives in the San Jerónimo district in the Angostura community, which is south of the city of Cusco. She has a stand in the Vino Canchón Market of San Jerónimo, where she sells food (breakfast, lunch, and dinner). She also raises guinea pigs and chickens. She has been working in the business for several years. It has gone very well for her thanks to all of the effort she puts into her work. She is an enterprising and hard-working mother who wants to get her family ahead. She needs the loan to buy supplies to make her dishes and to buy food for the animals she raises and later sells for a good price. This way she will be able to increase the capital in her business in order to have greater income. This will give her family a better quality of life. She is grateful for the opportunity of the loan, and she promises to pay it on time.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies to make her dishes and to buy food for the animals she raises

loans.name: Margine Del Socorro

texts.en:
Twenty years ago, Margine learned the art of selling clothes from her mother, whom she helped with her clothing sale business. With this loan, Margine will buy more clothing to resell. Margine is now 36 and has two children of her own, both of whom are in school. Margine’s goal is for her sons to obtain careers of their own, so that they are able to have more than she is able to provide.

Margine has an excellent credit history with Fundación León 2000. She says that her loans have helped her by maintaining her small business which provides a good income for her and her family. Margine worries about the unemployment that plagues Nicaragua.

loans.use: To buy clothing for resale

loans.name: Cruz

texts.en:
Cruz, or “Mimi” as she likes to be called, is a 48-year-old borrower from San Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic. She is a single mother of one, 13-year-old Cesar. This is her second loan with Esperanza International, and she will be using it to buy inventory for her Dominican eatery.

Mimi will be purchasing foods such as rice, beans, oil, flour, meats, juices, and other refreshments, to serve to her customers. She believes that her eatery is a place where “once you enter, you can’t leave” because you want to just keep eating! Mimi is obviously very confident in her business and excited for what the future has in store for her small restaurant.

Life in San Pedro can be rough: power outages happen daily (if one has power to begin with!), running water is scarce and never potable, and sanitation is limited. These facilities and services are especially inadequate in Mimi’s neighborhood. Despite these hardships, Mimi is very grateful for her work with Esperanza. She said that her business is steadily improving, and even though it may not seem like much, she knows her eatery is going places. Thank you for your support in lending to Mimi!

loans.use: To purchase oil, flour, chicken, rice, and beans for her eatery

loans.name: Francisca Susana

texts.es: Francisca Susana  es soltera, tiene 4 hijos, 3 son mayores y tienen su familia propia y le ayudan economicamente a su madre, solo tiene a cargo al menor de 17 años quien estudia su ultimo año de bachillerato.  Trabaja desde hace 6 años en el INACH de Juigalpa como conserje.  Esta solicitando su 5to credito a AFODENIC para mejorar su casa embaldosando su casa (sala y cuartos) pues actualmente es de tierra y durante el invierno se le hace lodo por las lluvias. Doña Francisca se caracteriza por ser muy responsable en sus compromisos, es muy querida por sus compañeros de trabajo que cariñosamente le dicen Susanita.  Ademas expresa sentirse agradecida con esta institucion porque gracias a los creditos que le brindan ha podido ir mejorando sus condiciones de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
Francisca Susana is a single mother with four children, three of whom are adults and have their own families. They help their mother financially. Francisca is responsible for her youngest child who is 17 years old and in the last year of high school. She has worked for six years as a caretaker for the organisation INACH in Juigalpa. She is seeking her fifth loan with Kiva partner AFODENIC to improve her house by tiling the living room and bedroom floors which are currently made of earth. During the winter rains they turn into mud. Doña Francisca is noted for living up to her commitments and is much liked by her work colleagues. To show their affection they have given her the nickname Susanita. Francisca feels very grateful for the loans extended to her by AFODENIC as they have enabled her to improve her own life and that of her family.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to tile the living room and bedroom floors

loans.name: Geyling De La Concepcion

texts.en:
Geyling was working for a local factory when she lost her job. Her aunt gave her a small amount of money so that she could begin her used clothing sale business. Geyling’s aunt lives in a central location, near one of the markets in the city of Leon, and lets Geyling use her house from which to sell.
 
Geyling has a good credit history with Fundación León 2000, but this is the first loan that she has used to support her business. Geyling is determined to continue with her business and dreams of opening up branches in other parts of the city and in other cities as well. Geyling is 27 years old and is a single mother to her six-year-old son. She says that being a single mother is a great challenge and she wishes that her son had more support.

loans.use: Capital for her used clothing sales business

loans.name: Romulo

texts.es:
El socio ROMULO pertenece al banco comunal “VIRGEN PURIFICADA - ANGOSTURA”.    

El socio tiene 42 años de edad, es conviviente y tiene dos hijos. El socio vive en la distrito de San Jerónimo en la comunidad de Angostura que se encuentra ubicada al sur de la ciudad del Cusco. Nuestro socio de dedica a la construcción es albañil y tiene un pequeño negocio de crianza de cuyes en su domicilio. Ya son veinte años que trabaja en el negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo, nuestro socio es una persona trabajadora y emprendedora que quiere sacar adelante a su familia. 

El socio requiere el préstamo para comprar más alimento para los animales que cría y después venderlos a un buen precio. Así de esta manera poder aumentar el capital del negocio pues para tener mejores ingresos y darle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida. 

El socio se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Romulo belongs to the Virgen Purificada-Angostura Communal Bank. He is 42, in a common law marriage, and has two children. He lives in the San Jerónimo district in the Angostura community, which is south of the city of Cusco. He works in construction as a bricklayer, and he has a small business raising guinea pigs in his home. He has worked in the business for 20 years. It has gone very well for him thanks to all of the effort he puts into his work. He is an enterprising and hard-working person who wants to get his family ahead. He needs the loan to buy more food for the animals he raises and later sells for a good price. This way he will be able to increase the capital in his business in order to have better income. Then he can give his family a better quality of life. He is grateful for the opportunity of the loan, and he promises to pay it on time.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more food for the animals he raises and later sells for a good price

loans.name: Mayra Azucena

texts.en:
Mayra began selling cosmetics, but after two years, she decided to sell used clothing instead. She buys the clothing in packets when she goes to Managua. Mayra says that this business has been of great help to her and her family. But a challenge of this business is that the price of the clothing packets has risen every month that she has bought them. 

Mayra is married and has two children. Her 26-year-old daughter is working and her 15-year-old son is in middle school. Mayra says that her loans have greatly supported her business and now she has a good inventory. Mayra’s goal is to further her business and help it to grow.

loans.use: Working capital for her used clothing sales business

loans.name: Luz Marina

texts.en: For six years, Senora Luz Marina has sold clothing, cosmetics, jewelry and perfumes. She says that she has many dreams, but most of all, she wants to have a store all her own. Luz Marina began her business when her partner left her and she had to find a way to support herself. The services of Fundación León 2000 have helped Luz Marina support her daughter’s education. Luz Marina also says that without these loans she would not be able to maintain her business. The only problem that she reports is that she has clients who are unable to pay what they owe her.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Embajadores 4 Group

texts.en:
Michelina is the coordinator of her group, Embajadores (Ambassadors), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural communities surrounding La Romana, an area famous for the sugarcane industry, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her partner and their three children.

Michelina is excited to be taking her fourth loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loans. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling clothes by purchasing skirts pants and shirts in bulk and then selling them at a profit in her neighborhood. She will use the profits to invest in her home and family by purchasing a small radio, painting the house, purchasing sandals and pants for her children and school supplies. Her long-term dream is to have a bigger business. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy more shirts, pants and skirts to sell in her store

loans.name: Gloria Dolores

texts.es: Gloria tiene varios financiamientos con Fundación León 2000, por lo que agradece mucho el apoyo brindado ya que s por medio de los financiamientos que estas personas pueden salir adelante. Su actividad económica es la elaboración y venta de comida, por lo que inicio de la necesidad de obtener una fuente de ingreso que para la alimentación diaria de su familia, y a pesar de haber tenido tantos problemas ha tenido mucha fuerza para salir adelante. Por lo que es una mujer muy responsable pues ella se preocupa por recoger las cuotas de su crédito. Ella solicita este financiamiento para la compra de granos básicos, refrescos naturales, leña y ciertos utensilios de cocina. El sueño de Gloria es ampliar su negocio para proporcionarles a sus clientes lo que solicitan.
texts.en:
Gloria has had several loans with Fundación León 2000 so she is thankful for the support she receives. Through these loans these people can get ahead. Gloria makes and sells food. Initially, it was to obtain a source of income in order to feed her family daily and in spite of having had many problems, she has had lots of strength to move forward. Since she is a very responsible woman, she is very concerned about collecting her loan payments. She requests this loan in order to buy basic grains, natural soft drinks, firewood and some kitchen utensils. Gloria’s dream is to expand her business in order to provide her clients with what they request.

Translated from Spanish by Lauren Jackson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Melchora

texts.es:
La socia MELCHORA es una humilde madre de familia que ya son varios años que pertenece al banco comunal “VIRGEN PURIFICADA - ANGOSTURA”.    

La socia tiene 45 años de edad, es casada y tiene cuatro hijos. La socia vive en el distrito de San Jerónimo en la comunidad de Angostura que se encuentra ubicada al sur de la ciudad del Cusco. Nuestra socia tiene una chacra donde siembra culantro, perejil, repollo, maíz y papas y después los cosecha y los distribuye a los mercados del Distrito. Nuestra socia alterna sus actividades del hogar, con el trabajo de la chacra y con la atención de su pequeña tienda de abarrotes. Ya son varios años que trabaja en el negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo, nuestra socia es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que quiere sacar adelante a su familia.
